Neuromodulin appears to interact with several second messenger systems in the growth cone and nerve terminal. The N-terminal domain of neuromodulin has been shown to stimulate GTP/GDP exchange on the α subunit of the GTP-binding proteins Go or Gi (47Strittmatter S.M. Valenzuela D. Kennedy T.E. Neer E.J. Fishman M.C. Nature. 1990; 344: 836-841Crossref PubMed Scopus (351) Google Scholar, 48Strittmatter S.M. Valenzuela D. Sudo Y. Linder M.E. Fishman M.C. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 22465-22471Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 49Strittmatter S.M. Igarashi M. Fishman M.C. J. Neurosci. 1994; 14: 5503-5513Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). Injection of neuromodulin or neuromodulin N-terminal peptides in cultured dorsal root ganglion neurons or Xenopus laevis oocytes enhanced G-protein-mediated intracellular signaling (50Strittmatter S.M. Cannon S.C. Ross E.M. Higashijima T. Fishman M.C. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 5327-5331Crossref PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar, 51Igarashi M. Strittmatter S.M. Vartanian T. Fishman M.C. Science. 1993; 259: 77-79Crossref PubMed Scopus (169) Google Scholar). In PC12 cells neuromodulin also appears to be modulate the function of L-type calcium channels, thereby affecting their electrical excitability (52Baetge E.E. Hammang J.P. Gribkoff V.K. Meiri K.F. Perspectives Dev. Neurobiol. 1992; 1: 21-28PubMed Google Scholar). Additionally, as an inhibitor of the phosphatidylinositol 4-phosphate kinase, neuromodulin influences the metabolism of phosphoinositides and may act therefore as a feedback inhibitor of calcium mobilization and PKC activity (53Jolles J. Zwiers H. Van Dongen C.J. Schotman P. Wirtz K.W.A. Gispen W.H. Nature. 1980; 286: 623-625Crossref PubMed Scopus (133) Google Scholar). Neuromodulin was also shown recently to be ADP-ribosylated (54Coggins P.J. McLean K. Nagy A. Zwiers H. J. Neurochem. 1993; 60: 368-371Crossref PubMed Scopus (31) Google Scholar); however, the functional significance of this is unknown. Neuromodulin has also been shown to bind to calmodulin, with a higher affinity in the absence of Ca2+ than is its presence. Calmodulin binding is also disrupted by phosphorylation of neuromodulin by the Ca2+/phospholipid-dependent PKC (55Chapman E.R. Au D. Alexander K.A. Nicolson T.A. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 207-213Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). These results have led to the hypothesis that neuromodulin serves to sequester calmodulin at the inner face of the plasma membrane in close proximity to calmodulin-dependent enzymes. Elevation of intracellular calcium would promote dissociation of calmodulin from neuromodulin, allowing the rapid activation of these substrates (56Liu Y. Storm D.R. Trends Pharmacol. Sci. 1990; 11: 107-111Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar, 57Estep R.P. Alexander K.A. Storm D.R. Curr. Top. Cell. Regul. 1990; 30: 161-180Crossref Scopus (28) Google Scholar, 58Apel E.D. Storm D.R. Perspectives Dev. Neurobiol. 1992; 1: 3-11PubMed Google Scholar). The abundance of neuromodulin in the nerve terminal, together with its relative affinity for calmodulin, suggests that neuromodulin might be a major neuronal calmodulin-binding protein. While studies have demonstrated that neuromodulin in synaptic plasma membranes binds exogenous radiolabeled calmodulin, the functional significance of the neuromodulin/calmodulin interaction in the intact cell remains to be explored. We reported recently that forced expression of neuromodulin in mouse anterior pituitary AtT-20 cells enhanced K+-evoked hormone secretion and induced changes in cellular morphology (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). These results suggested that AtT-20 cells would be a useful experimental system to explore the molecular mechanism(s) of neuromodulin action. Here, we describe the results of studies designed to test the hypothesis that neuromodulin modulates K+-evoked secretion from AtT-20 cells by sequestering CaM at the plasma membrane and releasing it upon elevation of intracellular Ca2+. The cDNAs encoding [Asp41]rat neuromodulin (55Chapman E.R. Au D. Alexander K.A. Nicolson T.A. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 207-213Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and [Gly3,Gly4] neuromodulin (60Chapman E.R. Estep R.P. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 25233-25238Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) were the generous gift of Dr. Dan Storm (University of Washington, Seattle). The expression vectors for these mutant forms of rat neuromodulin were produced by ligating a 750-base pair HindIII/EcoRI restriction fragment containing the mutated rat neuromodulin coding sequence into the HindIII and EcoRI sites of the pRc/RSV vector (Invitrogen) with the Rous sarcoma virus (RSV) promoter (61Gorman C. Padmanabhan R. Howard B.H. Science. 1983; 221: 551-553Crossref PubMed Scopus (449) Google Scholar) driving expression of the cDNA. All cell culture reagents were from Life Technologies, Inc. Monolayer cultures of D16 cells and transfected cell lines were maintained in 95% OptiMEM-I, 5% fetal bovine serum. The original AtT-20 cells were cultured in 85% OptiMEM-I, 10% equine serum, 5% fetal bovine serum; medium for routine culture of the transfected cells contained 200 μg/ml G418. All cell lines were incubated in humidified 95% air, 5% CO2 at 37°C. The AtT-20/D16 cells were generously provided by Dr. Lee Limbird, Department of Pharmacology, Vanderbilt University, and the original AtT-20 cells were obtained from the American Type Culture Collection (CCL89). The original AtT-20 cells were transfected using the LipofectAMINE reagent, according to the manufacturer's instructions as described previously (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Permanent transfected cell lines were selected in medium containing 400 μg/ml G418. Clones were then isolated by limiting dilution and expanded in culture. Primary cultures of rat hippocampal neurons, generously provided by Dr. Randy Hall and Andrès Barria-Roman, were prepared from rat pups 24-48 h post-natal. Hippocampi were dissected into room temperature osmotically balanced saline solution (SS: 137 mM NaCl, 5.3 mM KCl, 0.17 mM Na2HPO4, 0.22 mM KH2PO4, 10 mM Hepes, 33 mM glucose, 44 mM sucrose, 0.024 g/liter phenol red, pH 7.3, 325 mosm), cut into 5-6 pieces and incubated for 1 h with 10 ml of a 20 units/ml papain (Worthington) solution in SS. The papain solution was removed and the hippocampal fragments washed once in minimal essential medium supplemented with 10% heat-inactivated fetal calf serum, 1 μl/ml serum extender (Collaborative Research), 21 mM glucose, 10 μg/ml 5-fluoro-2′-deoxyuridine, 25 μg/ml uridine (Sigma) (complete medium). Cells were then dissociated into fresh complete medium via 15-20 passes through a Pasteur pipette and plated into sterile, poly-L-lysine-coated 35-mm culture plates at an approximate density of 2 hippocampi/dish. Cultures were fed on post-culture days 1, 4, and 7 and used for experiments on culture day 8. Cultures prepared via this method are of extremely high density (roughly 1-2 million cells/35-mm plate) and have a very high neuron-to-glia ratio since they are cultured in the presence of a mitotic inhibitor (5-fluoro-2′-deoxyuridine) from the first day. Cells were washed free of medium twice with Krebs-Ringer-Hepes (KRH) buffer (125 mM NaCl, 4.8 mM KCl, 2.6 mM CaCl2, 1.2 mM MgSO4, 25 mM Hepes, 5.6 mM glucose, pH 7.4) and incubated at 20°C for the indicated time with the thiol-cleavable homobifunctional cross-linker dithiobis(succinimidyl propionate) (DSP, Pierce) at 1 mM diluted in KRH from a 25 mM stock solution in Me2SO (cross-linked cells) or solvent alone (non-cross-linked cells). At the end of the incubation period, cells were transferred on ice, washed three times with ice-cold KRH, scraped off the dish, and cell pellets were frozen at −70°C until the immunoblot analysis was performed. To study the effects of calcium on the association of neuromodulin and CaM, cells were incubated for 5 min in KRH alone or KRH containing 0.1% dimethyl sulfoxide (Me2SO, vehicle for A23187) as controls, or KRH containing either 10 μM calcium ionophore A23187 (Sigma), or 56 mM KCl (in which the NaCl concentration was decreased to maintain iso-osmolarity) prior to treating the cells with DSP. To study the effects of PKC phosphorylation on the association of neuromodulin and CaM, cells were incubated for 5 min in KRH containing either 1 μM 12-O-tetradecanoylphorbol-13-acetate (TPA, Sigma) or 0.1% Me2SO (vehicle for TPA) as a control, prior to treating the cells with DSP. Total cellular protein and subcellular fractionation were performed as described (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Five hundred μg of protein were immunoprecipitated with an anti-rat neuromodulin polyclonal antibody (9de La Monte S.M. Federoff H.J. Ng S.C. Grabczyk E. Fishman M.C. Dev. Brain Res. 1989; 46: 161-168Crossref PubMed Scopus (166) Google Scholar) for 1 h on ice. Immune complexes were collected on protein A-Sepharose CL4B beads (Sigma) and washed once with 1 ml of 1 M NaCl, 1% Triton X-100; twice with 1 ml of radioimmune precipitation buffer, 1 M urea; and once with 1 ml of 10 mM Tris, 1 mM EDTA, pH 7.5. The material bound via the cross-linking agent to the neuromodulin immune complex was released by incubating the washed beads for 30 min at 37°C with elution buffer (10 mM Tris, pH 7.5, 5 mM EDTA, 0.2 M dithiothreitol), followed by a brief centrifugation. The eluate containing the material released from the immune complex by the reducing agent was analyzed by immunoblot analysis with an anti-calmodulin antibody. Immunoblot analysis was performed as described (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), using an anti-GAP-43 monoclonal antibody (clone GAP-7B10, Sigma,), or an anti-calmodulin monoclonal antibody (Upstate Biotechnology, Inc.), followed by a peroxidase-conjugated secondary antibody (Sigma,). Bound antibodies were detected by enhanced chemiluminescence (DuPont NEN) and exposure to x-ray film (X-Omat AR, Eastman Kodak Co.). Quantitation was done by scanning exposed films with the SigmaGel analysis software (Jandel Scientific Sofware). Secretion from the different cell lines was analyzed as described (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Secreted and cellular hormones were measured by radioimmunoassay. Net secretion (corticotrophin-releasing factor or K+-stimulated minus basal) was expressed as the percent of total cellular stores of β-endorphin released during the incubation period. β-endorphin immunoassays were performed as described previously (62Hatfield J.M. Allen R.G. Stack J. Ronnekleiv O. Dev. Biol. 1988; 126: 164-167Crossref PubMed Scopus (21) Google Scholar), using an antiserum that is specific for β-endorphin residues 15-26. Synthetic acetyl-β-endorphin 1-27 was used as tracer and standard, and a 12-point standard curve was assayed with each group of samples. The unpaired t test was used to determine the statistical significance of the results. Cells were loaded with Fura-2/acetoxy-methyl ester (fura2/AM, Molecular Probes) as described (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar) and fura-2 fluorescence was measured using a LS50 luminescence spectrometer (Perkin-Elmer). Ca2+ concentrations were calculated as described by Grynkiewicz et al. (63Grynkiewicz G. Poenie M. Tsien R.Y. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 3440-3450Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar), using the Intracellular Biochemistry software package (Perkin-Elmer). While neuromodulin has been shown to interact with CaM in vitro (64Andreasen T.J. Keller C.H. LaPorte D.C. Edelman A.M. Storm D.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1981; 78: 2782-2785Crossref PubMed Scopus (76) Google Scholar, 65Andreasen T.J. Luetje C.W. Heideman W. Storm D.R. Biochemistry. 1983; 22: 4615-4618Crossref PubMed Scopus (159) Google Scholar, 66Cimler B.M. Andreasen T.J. Andreasen K.I. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 10784-10788Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and in purified synaptosomal plasma membranes (67De Graan P.N.E. Oestreicher A.B. De Wit M. Krá;f M. Schrama L.H. Gispen W.H. J. Neurochem. 1990; 55: 2139-2141Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar), this interaction has yet to be demonstrated in vivo. Because the affinity of CaM for neuromodulin has been reported to be relatively low (68Alexander K.A. Cimler B.M. Meier K.E. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6108-6113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), we chose to use the approach of protein cross-linking to determine if CaM binds to neuromodulin in the intact cell. For these studies we used AtT-20/D16 (D16) cells, which express high levels of neuromodulin (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), and the thiol-cleavable homobifunctional cross-linker DSP, which due to its lipophilic nature penetrates into the cytoplasm of living cells (69de Gunzburg J. Riehl R. Weinberg R.A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 4007-4011Crossref PubMed Scopus (37) Google Scholar). Cultures of AtT-20/D16 cells were treated with 1 mM DSP for different times, and proteins were extracted and analyzed by Western blot with an anti-neuromodulin monoclonal antibody or with an anti-CaM monoclonal antibody. With both antibodies, a prominent 70-kDa band is detected and increases in intensity with increased time of cross-linking (Fig. 1A). Other neuromodulin immunoreactive bands are detected, with the 50-kDa band corresponding to that reported for native neuromodulin in a variety of studies (reviewed in 1Benowitz L.I. Routtenberg A. Trends Neurosci. 1987; 10: 527-532Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (458) Google Scholar); the higher molecular bands (>100 kDa) may correspond to neuromodulin complexed with actin, as these two proteins have also been shown to interact (70Strittmatter S.M. Vartanian T. Fishman M.C. J. Neurobiol. 1992; 23: 507-520Crossref PubMed Scopus (160) Google Scholar). Anti-CaM antibodies also detect a 20-kDa band corresponding to native CaM. The 70-kDa band is the result of cross-linking since it appears only after cross-linking (Fig. 1, B, lane 4; and C, lane 3) and is absent from membrane fractions from non cross-linked cells (Fig. 1, B, lane 2; and C, lane 1), or after reduction of cross-linked samples with β-mercaptoethanol (Fig. 1, B, lane 3; and C, lane 4). These results provide support for the notion that neuromodulin and CaM are associated in the intact AtT-20 cell. Quantitation by scanning densitometry indicates that as much as 70% of the CaM in the particulate fraction of AtT-20/D16 cells is present in this 70-kDa complex (Fig. 1C, lane 3). To analyze this association further, the original AtT-20 cells, which lack detectable expression of neuromodulin (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar), and the D16 cells were cross-linked as described previously, and neuromodulin and CaM were detected in particulate and soluble cellular fractions by immunoblot analysis with anti-neuromodulin or anti-CaM antibodies, respectively. Neuromodulin is detectable only in the particulate fraction of D16 cells (Fig. 2, lane 1) and is absent from the soluble fraction of the D16 cells and either fraction of the original AtT-20 cells (Fig. 2, lanes 2-4). Both cell lines have similar levels of CaM, which is mostly a soluble protein (Fig. 2, lanes 6 and 8), but some CaM is also present in membrane fractions (Fig. 2, lanes 5 and 7). In the particulate fraction from cross-linked D16 cells, which express neuromodulin, 70% of CaM is present in a 70-kDa complex (Fig. 2, lane 5). This complex is not detected in the absence of neuromodulin, either in the soluble fraction of D16 cells (Fig. 2, lane 6) or in the original AtT-20 cells (Fig. 2, lanes 7 and 8), suggesting that the 70-kDa complex results from the association of neuromodulin and CaM. Finally, immunoprecipitation of solubilized membrane proteins from cross-linked D16 cells with a polyclonal anti-neuromodulin antibody, followed by immunoblot analysis with a monoclonal anti-CaM antibody of the material eluted from the immune complex, provides additional evidence that CaM is associated with neuromodulin in the intact AtT-20 cells (Fig. 3). Extensive in vitro analysis of the neuromodulin-CaM interaction has demonstrated that the affinity of neuromodulin for CaM is higher in the absence of Ca2+ than in the presence of 1 mM Ca2+ (68Alexander K.A. Cimler B.M. Meier K.E. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6108-6113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), leading to the suggestion that an elevation of intracellular calcium would promote dissociation of calmodulin from neuromodulin (58Apel E.D. Storm D.R. Perspectives Dev. Neurobiol. 1992; 1: 3-11PubMed Google Scholar, 68Alexander K.A. Cimler B.M. Meier K.E. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6108-6113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). To determine if this is in fact occurring in the intact cell, we performed cross-linking and immunoblot experiments with D16 cells cultured in conditions that induce elevation of intracellular Ca2+. D16 cells were treated with the Ca2+ ionophore A23187 (10 μM) for 5 min at 20°C or with 0.1% Me2SO (control) and then cross-linked with 1 mM DSP for 5 min at 20°C, and membrane proteins were analyzed by immunoblot analysis with anti-neuromodulin and anti-CaM antibodies (Fig. 4A). In the absence of the Ca2+ ionophore, a prominent 70-kDa band corresponding to the neuromodulin-CaM complex was detectable with both antibodies (Fig. 4A, lanes 2 and 4). Treatment of the cells with the Ca2+ ionophore caused a marked reduction in the intensity of this 70-kDa band (approximately 90% reduction, as measured by scanning densitometry; Fig. 4A, lanes 1 and 3). Membrane depolarization is an alternative method for inducing an elevation of intracellular Ca2+ in AtT-20 cells (59Gamby C. Waage M.C. Allen R.G. Baizer L. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 10023-10028Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar). Cultures of D16 cells were therefore also incubated for 5 min in KRH solution containing 56 mM KCl, prior to cross-linking with DSP, followed by analysis of membrane extracts by immunoblot analysis (Fig. 4B). The transient elevation of intracellular Ca2+ produced by depolarization also caused a significant reduction of the complex

Guanosine 5′-O-(3-thiotriphosphate) (GTPγS) induces the translocation of glucose transporter type 4 (GLUT4) from an intracellular pool to the cell surface and increases glucose uptake in adipocytes. The GTP-binding protein(s) responsible for the translocation has remained to be identified. Using a sensitive and quantitative method to assess the translocation of c-MYC epitope-tagged GLUT4, we obtained evidence that the activation of receptor-coupled Gq (neither Gi nor Gs) triggered GLUT4 translocation in cells, independently of insulin signaling pathway(s). Platelet-activating factor (PAF) induced GLUT4 translocation in the cells expressing the Gi- and Gq-coupled PAF receptor, but the translocation was induced even after pretreatment with wortmannin, an islet-activating protein and phorbol 12,13-dibutyrate. Norepinephrine triggered GLUT4 translocation in cells expressing the Gq-coupled α1-adrenergic receptor, but prostaglandin E2 did not cause GLUT4 translocation in cells expressing the Gs-coupled EP4 receptor or the Gi-coupled EP3α receptor. The norepinephrine-stimulated GLUT4 translocation and glucose uptake via Gq may possibly contribute to the fuel supply required for thermogenesis in brown adipocytes and for the enhanced contractility in cardiomyocytes, both of which have an abundant endogenous GLUT4. The GLUT4 translocation and the enhanced glucose uptake are mediated insulin-independently via adrenergic receptors coupled to heterotrimeric GTP-binding proteins. However, the molecular mechanism of insulin-independent GLUT4 translocation was not elucidated. We report here that Gq-coupled receptors, but not Gi- nor Gs-coupled receptors, trigger GLUT4 translocation in an insulin-independent manner in 3T3-L1 adipocytes and CHO cells. The PMA-stimulated GLUT4myc translocations in 3T3-L1-GLUT4myc-PAFR adipocytes (1.3-fold increase) and CHO-GLUT4myc-PAFR cells (4.2-fold increase) were abolished by PDBu pretreatment that down-regulates protein kinase C, albeit the extent of translocation differing between the two lines (Figs. 2C and 3C). However, the same PDBu pretreatment had no apparent effects on the PAF-stimulated GLUT4myc translocation, in the both lines. In addition, PAF triggered GLUT4myc translocation (1.9-3.3-fold) and the resultant glucose uptake (2.3-fold) in both lines, even after simultaneous IAP, PDBu, and wortmannin treatment (Figs. 2, D and E, and 3D). To examine the effects of [Ca2+]i on the PAF-stimulated GLUT4myc translocation, we used two different Ca2+ ionophores. Ionomycin (1 μM) and PAF (2 × 10−8M) treatments elevated [Ca2+]i in CHO-GLUT4myc-PAFR cells, from basal levels (lower than 100 nM) up to about 900 and 600 nM, respectively, as in Fig. 4E. However, neither ionomycin (1 μM) nor A23187 (1 μM) led to GLUT4myc translocation in 3T3-L1-GLUT4myc-PAFR adipocytes and CHO-GLUT4myc-PAFR cells, whereas PAF evoked GLUT4myc translocation (Fig. 4, A and C). Depletion of [Ca2+]i by 1,2-bis-(O-aminophenoxy)ethane-N, N,N′,N′-tetraacetic acid acetoxymethyl ester (BAPTA-AM) (Fig. 4E), inhibited the PAF-stimulated GLUT4myc translocation, in both lines (Fig. 4, B and D). Thus, a certain level of [Ca2+]i was required for PAF-stimulated GLUT4myc translocation (see “Discussion”), but the elevation of [Ca2+]i was insufficient to cause GLUT4myc translocation. The leucine-responsive regulatory protein (Lrp) regulates the expression of many operons in Escherichia coli including several involved in the metabolism of the branched-chain amino acids, L-isoleucine, L-valine, and L-leucine. The ilvGMEDA operon contains the genes for four of the five enzymes of the common pathway for the biosynthesis of these amino acids. A high affinity, consensus-like Lrp-DNA binding site has been identified at an unusual position in the leader region of this operon 226 base pairs downstream of the transcriptional initiation site between the attenuator and the ilvG gene. Binding to this site facilitates the cooperative binding of a second Lrp protomer to an adjacent, upstream, secondary site. At higher Lrp concentrations, binding to a third site is observed. Chemical, enzymatic, and alkylation protection and interference footprinting experiments demonstrate that the Lrp homodimer contacts the DNA helix at symmetrical half-sites present in adjacent major grooves and that the primary and secondary binding sites are separated by one helical turn and aligned along the same face of the DNA helix. In vivo, Lrp represses transcription through the leader-attenuator region of the ilvGMEDA operon. Lrp-dependent production of attenuated RNA transcripts is also observed in vitro. No transcriptional effects are observed, in vivo or in vitro, in the absence of an intact Lrp primary binding site. A possible physiological role for Lrp in the regulation of ilvGMEDA operon expression is discussed. The leucine-responsive regulatory protein (Lrp) regulates the expression of many operons in Escherichia coli including several involved in the metabolism of the branched-chain amino acids, L-isoleucine, L-valine, and L-leucine. The ilvGMEDA operon contains the genes for four of the five enzymes of the common pathway for the biosynthesis of these amino acids. A high affinity, consensus-like Lrp-DNA binding site has been identified at an unusual position in the leader region of this operon 226 base pairs downstream of the transcriptional initiation site between the attenuator and the ilvG gene. Binding to this site facilitates the cooperative binding of a second Lrp protomer to an adjacent, upstream, secondary site. At higher Lrp concentrations, binding to a third site is observed. Chemical, enzymatic, and alkylation protection and interference footprinting experiments demonstrate that the Lrp homodimer contacts the DNA helix at symmetrical half-sites present in adjacent major grooves and that the primary and secondary binding sites are separated by one helical turn and aligned along the same face of the DNA helix. In vivo, Lrp represses transcription through the leader-attenuator region of the ilvGMEDA operon. Lrp-dependent production of attenuated RNA transcripts is also observed in vitro. No transcriptional effects are observed, in vivo or in vitro, in the absence of an intact Lrp primary binding site. A possible physiological role for Lrp in the regulation of ilvGMEDA operon expression is discussed.

To ascertain the anionic sites on the nicotinic receptor to which acetylcholine and other quaternary ammonium ligands bind, we have examined the role of an aspartyl residue (Asp-152) in the α-subunit. Prior photolytic labeling with agonist analogues of the neighboring residues Trp-149 and Tyr-151 suggests that their side chains reside on the binding face (also termed the (+)- or counterclockwise face) of the α-subunit. Asp-152 presents an anionic charge in the vicinity of these aromatic residues. Modification of the aspartate to asparagine (D152N) creates a glycosylation signal (Asn-152-Gly-Ser), and we find, on the basis of altered electrophoretic migration, that glycosylation occurs at this position upon cotransfection of the mutant α-subunit with β-, γ-, and δ-subunits. Glycosylation results in a reduction in the capacity of the receptor to assemble; this reduction is manifest in the initial step of dimer formation between the αγ- and αδ-subunits. The α-subunit mutant receptor reaching the assembled pentamer exhibits an altered selectivity for certain ligands. Little reduction in α-bungarotoxin binding is observed, whereas affinities for agonists and competitive alkaloid antagonists are reduced substantially. Separation of the contributions of charge removal and glycosylation addition shows that both factors affect agonist affinity, with the charge influence being far more predominant. These findings raise the possibility that a component of the coulombic attraction stabilizing the binding of agonists comes from the aspartyl residue at position 152 in the α-subunit. The nicotinic acetylcholine receptor in muscle is a pentamer of four homologous subunits with a stoichiometry of α2βγδ (15Galzi J.L. Changeux J.-P. Curr. Opin. Struct. Biol. 1994; 4: 554-565Crossref Scopus (198) Google Scholar and Changeux, 1994; 23Karlin A. Akabas M.H. Neuron. 1995; 15: 1231-1244Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (561) Google Scholar and Akabas, 1995). The subunits appear to contain an amino-terminal extracellular domain of ∼210 amino acids, followed by four transmembrane-spanning regions. The majority of the cytoplasmic domain of each subunit is found between transmembrane spans 3 and 4. Since the sequences between transmembrane spans 2 and 3 and between span 4 and the carboxyl terminus are of limited length, virtually all of the extracellular domain is contained in the amino-terminal 210 residues. Indeed, the residues constituting the binding sites for agonists and competitive antagonists appear in this region (cf. Galzi and Changeux (1994), 40Sine S.M. Kreienkamp H.-J. Bren N. Maeda R.K. Taylor P. Neuron. 1995; 15: 205-211Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (175) Google Scholar et al. (1995a), and Karlin and Akabas (1995)), as do the residues that govern subunit assembly (18Gu Y. Camacho P. Gardner P. Hall Z.W. Neuron. 1991; 6: 879-887Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar et al., 1991; 26Kreienkamp H.-J. Maeda R.K. Sine S.M. Taylor P. Neuron. 1995; 14: 636-644Abstract Full Text PDF Scopus (92) Google Scholar et al., 1995). Two binding sites for agonists are found on each pentamer and reside at the αγ- and αδ-interfaces (4Blount P. Merlie J.P. Neuron. 1989; 3: 349-357Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (225) Google Scholar and Merlie, 1989; 34Petersen S.E. Cohen J.B. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2785-2789Crossref PubMed Scopus (223) Google Scholar and Cohen, 1990). Through affinity labeling and site-specific mutagenesis, three distinct domains in the α-subunit appear to be involved in ligand binding: the regions in the vicinity of Tyr-93 and Trp-149 and the region between residues 180 and 200 (cf. Galzi and Changeux (1994) and Karlin and Akabas (1995)). Since the same face of the α-subunit is involved in the binding interaction for those ligands that differ in affinity at the αγ- and αδ-interfaces, the distinctions must come from residues located on the γ- and δ-subunits. While isolated α-subunits will bind the elapid α-toxins with moderately high affinities, addition of γ- or δ-subunits results in a binding site in which the α-toxin affinity is increased substantially and carbamylcholine or other agonists become competitive with α-toxin binding (Blount and Merlie, 1989; 37Sine S.M. Claudio T. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 19369-19377Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and Claudio, 1991). Several non-α-subunit residues (Lys-34, Trp-55, Ser-111, Tyr-117, Phe-172, and Asp-174 in γ and the corresponding positions in δ) contribute to ligand specificity. Their involvement has been ascertained through site-directed labeling (7Chiara D.C. Cohen J.B. Biophys. J. 1992; 61 (abstr.): A106Google Scholar and Cohen, 1992), site-specific mutagenesis (36Sine S.M. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 9436-9440Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar, 1993; 33O'Leary M.E. Filato G.N. White M.M. Am. J. Physiol. 1994; 266: C648-C653Crossref PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1994; 11Czajkowski C. Kaufmann C. Karlin A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1993; 90: 6285-6289Crossref PubMed Scopus (106) Google Scholar et al., 1993; Sine et al., 1995a; 9Corringer P.-J. Galzi J.-L. Eisele J.-L. Bertrand S. Changeux J.-P. Bertrand D. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11749-11752Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar et al., 1995), and chemical cross-linking (10Czajkowski C. Karlin A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 3160-3164Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (94) Google Scholar and Karlin, 1995). Of these residues, only Asp-174 in the γ-subunit or Asp-180 in the δ-subunit is negatively charged, and chemical cross-linking between Cys-192 or Cys-193 in the α-subunit and Asp-180 in the δ-subunit raised the possibility that an anionic subsite is found on the neighboring subunit (Czajkowski and Karlin, 1995). More recently, mutagenesis studies have shown a marked reduction in agonist affinity upon neutralization of γ-Asp-174 or δ-Asp-180 (28Martin M. Czajkowski C. Karlin A. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 13497-13503Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (54) Google Scholar et al., 1996). As such, a bound ligand such as acetylcholine would span between the subunits. However, lophotoxin, a rigid cyclic analogue of acetylcholine, has been shown to label Tyr-190 in the α-subunit (1Abramson S.N. Li Y. Culver P. Taylor P. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 12666-12672Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1989). The reactive moiety in lophotoxin is an electrophile with a partial positive charge (Abramson et al., 1991). Since the reactive electrophile might be expected to occupy the same site on the receptor as the quaternary group in acetylcholine, an anionic side chain in the α-subunit may also contribute to quaternary ligand stabilization. To examine this possibility, we have mutated candidate anionic residues in the α-subunit. Since prior studies have shown that regions on the α-subunit binding face around residues 93 and 149 and between residues 180 and 200 contribute to ligand binding, aspartates and glutamates in this vicinity were initially investigated. α-125I-Bungarotoxin (specific activity of 8-16 μCi/μg) was a product of DuPont NEN. Dimethyl-d-tubocurarine was obtained from Lilly. Other biochemical reagents were obtained from Sigma. The monoclonal antibody 210, directed against the α-subunit, was a generous gift of Dr. Jon Lindstrom (University of Pennsylvania). Double-stranded plasmids containing the cDNA sequences of the four receptor subunits used for mutagenesis and expression were prepared as described by 25Kreienkamp H.-J. Sine S.M. Maeda R.K. Taylor P. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 8108-8114Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al. (1994). To prepare single-stranded plasmids for mutagenesis, plasmids containing a cDNA encoding the mouse muscle α-subunit were transfected into competent CJ236 bacteria and selected in ampicillin and chloramphenicol. Helper phage stock was added; further selection was accomplished with kanamycin; and single-stranded plasmids were isolated following polyethylene glycol precipitation and extraction with chloroform/phenol. Mutagenesis was performed using the above single-stranded templates (27Kunkel T.A. Roberts J.D. Zakour R.A. Methods Enzymol. 1987; 154: 367-382Crossref PubMed Scopus (4540) Google Scholar et al., 1987). Following a synthesis reaction, double-stranded plasmids were isolated from DH5α bacterial cells by CsCl density centrifugation. DNA sequence changes were detected by restriction mapping and verified by dideoxy-DNA sequencing. cDNAs encoding wild-type α-, β-, γ-, and δ-subunits and mutant α-subunits were placed in an expression plasmid containing a cytomegalovirus promoter. The cDNAs were transfected using Ca3(PO4)2 into human embryonic kidney (HEK-293) cells at a stoichiometric ratio of α2 (15 μg)/β (7.5 μg)/γ (7.5 μg)/δ (7.5 μg), α2/β/γ2, or α2/β/δ2 (Kreienkamp et al., 1995; 41Sine S.M. Ohno K. Bouzat C. Auerbach A. Milone M. Praitt J.N. Engle A.G. Neuron. 1995; 15: 229-239Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (224) Google Scholar et al., 1995a). Receptor expression was typically measured 48 h after transfection. For receptor binding assays, cells were harvested by treating plates with phosphate-buffered saline containing 5 mM EDTA. The cells were gently sedimented by centrifugation and resuspended in Ringer K+ buffer, and the specified concentrations of ligands were added. For electrophoresis and Western blotting, after the culture medium was removed, the plates were washed three times in phosphate-buffered saline. The cells were harvested with phosphate-buffered saline/EDTA, sedimented, and resuspended in an appropriate buffer. To ascertain whether additional glycosylation occurred in the αD152N mutant receptor, we examined the migration positions of the α-subunit by polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis in the presence of SDS. Washed and resuspended cells in amounts to give 200 fmol of α-125I-bungarotoxin sites (typically from a confluent 10-cm plate) were solubilized in Laemmli sample buffer and separated on 8-cm 10% polyacrylamide gels as described previously (24Keller S.H. Kreienkamp H.-J. Kawanishi C. Taylor P. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 4165-4171Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (26) Google Scholar et al., 1995). The migration positions of the α-subunits were detected by Western blot analysis using mAb 210 directed against the α-subunit. Assembly of receptor subunits was analyzed by transfection of the cDNAs at the described stoichiometric ratios. After 48 h, cells were harvested and incubated with 20 nMα-125I-bungarotoxin for 2 h. The cells were subsequently sedimented and washed three times in Ringer K+ buffer. Bound α-125I-bungarotoxin was quantitated by γ-counting. Association and dissociation rates for α-bungarotoxin were measured as described by Kreienkamp et al. (1994). For association measurements, α-125I-bungarotoxin (20 nM) was added to cells, and the reaction was stopped at appropriate times by placing an aliquot of cells into an excess of carbamylcholine. Unbound α-toxin was washed away, and the cells were sedimented. Nonspecific α-toxin binding was measured by prior incubation of the cells in 10 mM carbamylcholine and determination of bound α-toxin at various times. For dissociation rate measurements, cells were incubated in 40 nMα-125I-bungarotoxin for at least 2 h. The cells were diluted into a large volume of Ringer K+ buffer; α-toxin was allowed to dissociate; and cells were washed free of α-toxin at specified times. Dissociation constants were calculated by assuming bimolecular association and unimolecular dissociation processes. Dissociation constants for the various ligands were measured by competition with the initial rate of α-125I-bungarotoxin binding after prior equilibration with the ligand (38Sine S. Taylor P. J. Biol. Chem. 1979; 254: 3315-3325Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and Taylor, 1979; Kreienkamp et al., 1994). Cells were harvested by permeabilization with a saponin-containing buffer (10 mM NaPO4 (pH 7.0), 10 mM EDTA, 0.1% bovine serum albumin, and a 0.5% saponin) and incubated with 10 nMα-125I-bungarotoxin for 2 h on ice. Cells were washed free of unbound radioactivity with Ringer K+ buffer. The cell pellets were solubilized on ice in 200 μl of Triton X-100-containing buffer (1% Triton X-100, 150 mM NaCl, 5 mM EDTA, and 50 mM Tris-HCl (pH 7.5)). After 3-4 h, insoluble matter was sedimented, and the supernatants were layered on 12-ml 3-30% sucrose gradients in the same buffer and detergent. Gradients were centrifuged in a Beckman SW 41 rotor for 22 h at 40,000 rpm at 4°C. The gradients were collected from the top in fractions of 240 or 266 μl and counted in a γ-counter. S values were determined by adding carbonic anhydrase (3.3 S), alkaline phosphatase (6.1 S), catalase (11 S), and β-galactosidase (16 S) to the cell extracts and determining their activities in the gradient fractions. Asp-89 and Asp-97 are conserved throughout all subunits and may be responsible for proper folding of the subunits. Asp-99 is found as a diacidic amino acid in all α-subunits except α7, where it is replaced by arginine. Its absence in α7 might suggest that another anionic residue subserves this role in α7-containing pentamers. In Domain III, α-Glu-180 and Asp-200 are possible candidates, but other functional and structural considerations would argue that they are less likely to reside on a binding interface. First, mutation of Asp-200 led to little change in ligand binding or in agonist-elicited responses (O'Leary et al., 1994). Second, α-Glu-180 lies sufficiently far in sequence from Tyr-190 that it may reside closer to a nonbinding face of the subunit. Since mutation at position 152 results in insertion of a consensus glycosylation signal (Asn-X-Ser), ascertaining whether glycosylation occurs should allow discrimination between the influences of addition of an oligosaccharide and charge neutralization on receptor assembly and ligand binding behavior. Following expression of the α-subunit with β-, γ-, and δ-subunits, extraction of the cells and electrophoresis on polyacrylamide gels in the presence of SDS reveal that insertion of a glycosylation signal at position 152 (Asn-152-Gly-Ser) results in retardation of the migrating α-subunit when compared with the wild-type α-subunit. An additional mutation (S154A), which eliminates the essential hydroxylated side chain requirement in the glycosylation signal, results in the migration rate of the α-subunit returning to a value similar to that in the wild-type α-subunit (Fig. 1). Thus, residue 152, when mutated from Asp to Asn, becomes glycosylated. Similar reductions in migration of the α-subunit were observed previously when glycosylation signals were inserted at positions 187 and 189 in the α-subunit and could be reversed by substitution for the serine or threonine two residues carboxyl-terminal to the Asn (Keller et al., 1995). Fig. 2 shows that the mutation D152N reduces expression of the receptor on the cell surface when cDNAs encoding the various subunit combinations known to reach the cell surface are transfected into HEK cells. Expression of a receptor as α2βγδ, using four subunits in the transfection mixture, yields the greatest expression compared with α2βγ2 and α2βδ2 (Sine and Claudio, 1991; 17Green W.N. Claudio T. Cell. 1993; 74: 57-69Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (120) Google Scholar and Claudio, 1993). Glycosylation of the α-subunit shows a reduction in subunit assembly and export of receptor to the cell surface. The greatest reduction in assembly for the three combinations of assembled pentamer was found for the α2βγ2 combination (Fig. 2B). Elimination of the glycosylation signal by a serine to alanine mutation at position 154 substantially increases cell-surface expression, but not quite to the level seen with the wild-type receptor. To examine whether the reduction in cell-surface expression occurs in an initial assembly step of subunits or in the translocation of the assembled pentamer to the cell surface, we examined intracellular assembly of dimeric forms of the receptor in permeabilized cells. As seen in Fig. 3, the D152N mutation reduces the formation of αδ-dimers, αγ-dimers, and αγαγ-tetramers. The reduction in intermediate dimer formation was also observed when the β-subunit was transfected with the pairs of α- and γ-subunits or α- and δ-subunits (data not shown). Although the major peak, by far, is the monomeric species with the D152N mutation, a definite skewing of the peak shapes is evident in the gradients, suggesting association of the α-subunit to form small quantities of oligomeric receptor species. Presumably sufficient assembly of dimers is occurring to allow sequential assembly and formation of pentameric receptor, but in greatly reduced quantities (Fig. 2). To ascertain whether glycosylation is limiting for dimer formation, we also monitored subunit assembly for the double mutant αD152N,S154A. Serine is found at this position in only a few of the receptor subunits and not in all α-subunits (Table I). The sedimentation profiles show discrete peaks for the dimeric (αγ and αδ) and tetrameric (αγαγ) species (Fig. 3). This profile of enhanced assembly is consistent with an increased level of expression on the cell surface for the receptor containing the double mutant compared with the single mutant in the α-subunit. Hence, the enhanced capacity to form dimers intracellularly in the initial step increases the abundance of partially assembled precursors for formation of pentameric receptors on the cell surface. Sufficient receptor containing the mutation αD152N does appear on the cell surface to enable an analysis of ligand specificity. Analysis of association and dissociation rates for α-125I-bungarotoxin shows the respective rate constants to be virtually unchanged (Fig. 4 and Table II). Similar behavior is seen for the D152N,S154A mutation, with little change in association kinetics (Fig. 4 and Table II). Pharmacol. 1994; 46: 858-865PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1994). The dissociation constants of the agonists and antagonists for D152Q closely resemble those found for the αD152N,S154A mutant (Table II). The elimination of charge on an aspartyl residue at position 152 in the α-subunit of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor alters both the capacity for assembly with other subunits and the ligand specificity of the assembled receptor. We selected this residue based on a survey of charged residues in the regions of the α-subunit known to affect ligand binding and therefore presumed to be located at the binding site. This face of the α-subunit should be in apposition with an opposing face of the γ- or δ-subunit. Obviously, with only fragmentary data on the overall structure of the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor, we cannot exclude the involvement of other anionic residues in the α-subunit contributing to receptor assembly or ligand specificity. Moreover, mutations that generate glycosylation signals at amino acid positions found in α-neurotoxin-resistant animal species appear to sterically inhibit α-toxin binding (Kreienkamp et al., 1994; Keller et al., 1995). These residues, which exist as asparagines in the resistant species, are found at positions 187 and 189 and are presumably exposed at the cell surface. The D152N mutation retards electrophoretic mobility of the α-subunit to a similar extent as mutations known to place a glycosylation signal at positions 187 and 189 (Keller et al., 1995). Glycosylation at position 152, which appears complete in the gene product of transfection (Fig. 1), suggests that this asparagine is a surface residue. Inhibition of αD152N receptor expression appears to be a consequence of the initial association of α- and γ-subunits and of α- and δ-subunits. Inhibition at this step is completely consistent with the location of Asp-152 on the (+)- or counterclockwise face of the α-subunit, in apposition with residues on the (−)- or clockwise face of the γ- and δ-subunits. The finding that residual assembly still occurs to form a pentameric receptor indicates that the oligosaccharide linked to Asn-152 does not occlude the contact residues from forming the interface between subunits. Ile-145 and Thr-150 on the γ-subunit also appear on the counterclockwise face since their mutations to lysines found in the δ-subunit preclude formation of αγαγ-tetramers from αγ-dimers, but not the initial formation of the αγ-dimers (Kreienkamp et al., 1995). Modification of α-Asp-152 to Asn with its isosteric neutral side chain reveals the combined influence of charge neutralization and oligosaccharide addition on receptor assembly and binding parameters. Substitution of Ser-154, the other required component in the N-linked glycosylation signal, enabled us to dissect the individual contributions, and this has yielded some unanticipated findings. First, the lack of influence of glycosylation on α-toxin binding kinetics contrasts with the results of other asparagine-linked glycosylation additions, which also reside in the vicinity of the ligand-binding site. The α-subunits of nicotinic receptors from the snake (Naja) and the mongoose have glycosylation signals at residues 187 and 189, respectively (31Neumann J. Barchan D. Horowitz M. Kochva E. Fuchs S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1989; 86: 7255-7259Crossref PubMed Scopus (60) Google Scholar et al., 1989; 3Barchan D. Kachalsky S. Neumann D. Vogel A. Ovadia N. Kochva E. Fuchs S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1992; 89: 7717-7721Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar et al., 1992). Insertion of glycosylation signals at these positions in the mouse α-subunit template leads to additional glycosylation and results in a reduction in α-toxin affinity (Keller et al., 1995). Since the oligosaccharides at positions 187 and 189 primarily affect the binding of the large α-toxins and not the smaller peptide or alkaloid antagonists, their influence on ligand binding is presumed to arise from imposition of steric constraints in the binding site (Kreienkamp et al., 1994). By contrast, oligosaccharide conjugation at position 152 interferes only with binding of the smaller ligands. Hence, the D152N-conjugated oligosaccharide is not likely to be positioned near the loop tips of the interacting α-toxin, the presumed point of interaction between the α-toxin and the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor (44Tremeau O. Lemaire C. Drevet P. Pinkasfeld S. Ducancel F. Boulain J.-C. Menez A. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 9362-9369Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (131) Google Scholar et al., 1995). Oligosaccharide conjugation per se has only a small influence on agonist binding (4-5-fold). Similarly, glycosylation of Asn-189 in the mouse mutant α-subunit, despite its proximity to a critical Tyr-190, does not influence the binding of small ligands (Kreienkamp et al., 1994; Keller et al., 1995). This suggests some flexibility of the oligosaccharide chain and its linkage to the asparaginyl residue. It is not surprising that charge neutralization at a single position has a minimal effect on α-toxin binding. The α-toxins contain multiple positive charges, and elimination of a single negative charge on the receptor may have minimal influence on the binding kinetics, particularly if the charges contribute primarily to long-range electrostatic attractive forces. For example, x-ray crystallographic studies show that the interaction of fasciculin, a three-fingered toxin homologous to α-bungarotoxin, involves primarily hydrophobic interactions with the acetylcholinesterase surface (5Bourne Y. Taylor P. Marchot P. Cell. 1995; 83: 503-512Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (319) Google Scholar et al., 1995; 19Harel M. Kleywegt G.J. Ravelli R.B.G. Silman I. Sussman J.L. Structure. 1995; 3: 1355-1366Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (221) Google Scholar et al., 1995), and mutagenesis studies indicate that a complement of hydrophobic surfaces seems most critical for high affinity binding. 1P. 3ot, C. Prowse, and P. Taylor, unpublished observations. Charge neutralization has a greater influence than glycosylation on reducing the affinity of agonists and antagonists (carbamylcholine, suberyldicholine, decamethonium, d-tubocurarine, and dimethyl-d-tubocurarine) for the receptor (Table II). All of these compounds share at least one quaternary moiety, and the elimination of a coulombic interaction is the likely shared basis for the reduction in affinity for the full agonists and antagonists. Since the reductions in affinity of the full agonists, suberyldicholine and carbamylcholine, are comparable to those found for the partial agonists and the antagonists, the mutation, leading to a generalized loss in affinity, is not specifically associated with agonist-induced changes in receptor state. Moreover, since the loss of affinity is comparable for mono- and bis-quaternary ligands, this residue probably is not primarily involved in stabilization of the second cationic site for bis-quaternary ligands. A mutation in a neighboring residue (αG153S) was found in a patient with a slow channel syndrome (Sine et al., 1995b). This mutation increases agonist affinity, resulting in a decreased rate of acetylcholine dissociation and repeated channel opening during the interval of agonist occupation. Hence, four residues in this region of adjoining sequence (Trp-149, Tyr-151, Asp-152, and Gly-153) have all provided evidence of being proximal to the binding site. The finding that the charge on Asp-152 is a major determinant of agonist and antagonist binding raises several interesting questions regarding the subunit location and disposition of residues that stabilize the quaternary ammonium-containing agonists and antagonists. In proteins containing a binding site of similar recognition capacity for quaternary ligands and whose structure has been resolved, one finds proximal aromatic residues surrounding a large portion of the quaternary ion (14Dougherty D.A. Stauffer D.A. Science. 1990; 250: 1558-1560Crossref PubMed Scopus (572) Google Scholar and Stauffer, 1990), but, in addition, the site is characterized by more distant anionic residue(s) (Segal et al., 1974; 42Sussman J.L. Harel M. Frolow F. Oefner C. Goldman A. Toker L. Silman I. Science. 1991; 253: 872-879Crossref PubMed Scopus (2389) Google Scholar et al., 1991). These results are consistent with short-range (1/r6) hydrophobic and longer range (1/r) electrostatic energy contributing to stabilization of quaternary ligands (13Dougherty D.A. Science. 1996; 271: 163-168Crossref PubMed Scopus (2319) Google Scholar, 1996). Acetylcholinesterase (Sussman et al., 1991) and the Fab fragment of an antibody binding phosphorylcholine (35Segal D.M. Padlan E.A. Cohen G.H. Rudikoff S. Potter M. Davies D.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1974; 71: 4295-4302Google Scholar et al., 1974) have their binding sites contained within a single subunit, whereas a binding site at the interface of two subunits has evolved for the nicotinic acetylcholine receptor. Karlin and co-workers (Czajkowski et al., 1993; Martin et al., 1996) have shown that the aspartyl residues δ-Asp-180 and γ-Asp-174 are cross-linked by a bifunctional reagent to α-Cys-192 and/or α-Cys-193 and therefore must reside within 9 Å of one of the two cysteines in the α-subunit. Removal of the charge on δ-Asp-180 or γ-Asp-174 also reduces acetylcholine affinity by ∼2 orders of magnitude (Czajkowski et al., 1993; Martin et al., 1996), and these investigators suggested that the agonist spans the subunit interface. The loss of binding energy may be a consequence of the absence of an agonist-mediated change in receptor conformation to a higher affinity or desensitized state. Our studies with α-Asp-152 reopen the question of whether the electrostatic attractive forces arise from a single charged residue across the αγ- and αδ-subunit interfaces on the γ- and δ-subunits or from a residue on the α-subunit. The long-range nature of electrostatic point charges is also consistent with several charges contributing to an electrostatic field at the subunit interface. Charge neutralization at α-Asp-152 only minimally affects assembly at the αγ- and αδ-interfaces. It is not known whether the D180N mutation in the δ-subunit or D174N in the γ-subunit will influence receptor subunit assembly. In fact, mutations in α-, γ-, or δ-subunits that alter subunit alignment upon assembly could affect ligand binding by simply restricting the conformational changes induced by binding of the respective ligands to achieve high affinity or desensitized states. The cyclic diterpenes of the lophotoxin family possess an electrophilic site at C(7)-C(8) that reacts with Tyr-190 in the α-subunit (Abramson et al., 1989). Since the lophotoxin lactone structurally resembles acetylcholine, and bromoacetylcholine is known to react with Cys-192 or Cys-193 (22Karlin A. J. Gen. Physiol. 1969; 54: 245S-264SCrossref PubMed Scopus (163) Google Scholar, 1969), as noted previously, the ester moiety of bound acetylcholine would be expected to lie antiparallel to the amide bond in the peptide chain in this region of the α-subunit (2Abramson S.N. Trischman J.A. Tapiolas D.M. Herold E.E. Fenical W. Taylor P. J. Med. Chem. 1991; 34: 1798-1804Crossref PubMed Scopus (69) Google Scholar et al., 1991). This orientation suggests that Tyr-190 is closer to the position of the anionic charge(s) than are cysteines at positions 192 and 193; Asp-152 in the α-subunit, Asp-174/Asp-180 in the γ/δ-subunits, or both of the side chains might well lie close to α-Tyr-190.

The self-glucosylating proteins, Glg1p and Glg2p, are required for glycogen synthesis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Cheng, C., Mu., J., Farkas, I., Huang, D., Goebl M. G., and Roach, P. J. (1995) Mol. Cell. Biol. 15, 6632-6640). Glg2p was shown to be associated with carbohydrate in vivo and was released from the high molecular weight glycogen fraction by treatment with α-amylase. In addition, some Glg2p exists as a protein of Mr∼43,000, whose proportion is increased in cells lacking glycogen synthase. Unlike the mammalian counterpart, glycogenin, the yeast Glg proteins appear to require multiple Tyr residues for functionality. In Glg2p, mutation of both Tyr230 and Tyr232 is necessary to suppress self-glucosylation of purified protein in vitro. The mutant protein is still capable of transferring glucose to an exogeneous acceptor, n-dodecyl β-D-maltoside. A small COOH-terminal region, conserved between Glg1p and Glg2p, is also important for function; mutation of Tyr367 or truncation at residue 362 impairs the ability of primed Glg2p to be elongated by glycogen synthase. Complete suppression of glycogen accumulation in vivo requires mutation of all three Tyr residues. In Glg1p, two Tyr residues are implicated, Tyr232 and Tyr600, mutation of both being required to eliminate glycogen accumulation in vivo. The self-glucosylating proteins, Glg1p and Glg2p, are required for glycogen synthesis in Saccharomyces cerevisiae (Cheng, C., Mu., J., Farkas, I., Huang, D., Goebl M. G., and Roach, P. J. (1995) Mol. Cell. Biol. 15, 6632-6640). Glg2p was shown to be associated with carbohydrate in vivo and was released from the high molecular weight glycogen fraction by treatment with α-amylase. In addition, some Glg2p exists as a protein of Mr∼43,000, whose proportion is increased in cells lacking glycogen synthase. Unlike the mammalian counterpart, glycogenin, the yeast Glg proteins appear to require multiple Tyr residues for functionality. In Glg2p, mutation of both Tyr230 and Tyr232 is necessary to suppress self-glucosylation of purified protein in vitro. The mutant protein is still capable of transferring glucose to an exogeneous acceptor, n-dodecyl β-D-maltoside. A small COOH-terminal region, conserved between Glg1p and Glg2p, is also important for function; mutation of Tyr367 or truncation at residue 362 impairs the ability of primed Glg2p to be elongated by glycogen synthase. Complete suppression of glycogen accumulation in vivo requires mutation of all three Tyr residues. In Glg1p, two Tyr residues are implicated, Tyr232 and Tyr600, mutation of both being required to eliminate glycogen accumulation in vivo.

Binding of natural antibodies to endothelial cell plays an important role in hyperacute xenograft rejection between discordant species. Human intravenous immunoglobulins (IVIg) delay this hyperacute rejection, but their mechanisms of action on endothelial cells have to be defined. Here we demonstrate that IVIg dose-dependently prevent thrombin from eliciting cytosolic Ca2+ movements and nitric oxide (NO) production in aortic endothelial cells from guinea pig. The Ca2+ response to thrombin was similarly affected by IVIg whether they were removed or not from the incubation medium before stimulation. Pretreatment by rat natural antibodies also suppress the thrombin-induced Ca2+ peak corresponding to Ca2+ release from intracellular stores but stimulate the subsequent sustained increase in [Ca2+]i and the release of NO. The action of human intravenous immunoglobulins seems to be selective for the thrombin receptor because they do not affect [Ca2+]i and NO responses to endothelin-1 or thapsigargin. However, these antibodies also suppress the first phase of the cytosolic Ca2+ response to ATP, which does not release NO under our experimental conditions. These observations raise the possibility that IVIg selectively interact with targets localized on plasma membrane of endothelial cells for controlling receptor-activated Ca2+ pathways and NO release.
