Integrins not only mediate cell-cell and cell-matrix interactions, they also trigger intracellular signaling events that lead to changes in cellular function (1Clark E.A. Brugge J.S. Science. 1995; 268: 233-239Crossref PubMed Scopus (2822) Google Scholar). In platelets, the major integrin is the αIIbβ3-integrin (glycoprotein IIb-IIIa complex). Upon activation of platelets, the αIIbβ3 complex changes its conformation and becomes competent to bind fibrinogen and other adhesive proteins, such as fibronectin and von Willebrand factor (2Siess W. Physiol. Rev. 1989; 69: 58-178Crossref PubMed Scopus (793) Google Scholar). The conformational change of the αIIbβ3-integrin can be induced by physiological stimuli, such as thrombin or ADP, through inside-out signaling (3O'Toole T.E. Mandelman D. Forsyth J. Shattil S.J. Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. Science. 1991; 254: 845-847Crossref PubMed Scopus (275) Google Scholar, 4Shattil S.J. Cunningham M. Wiedmer T. Zhao J. Sims P.J. Brass L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 18424-18431Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 5O'Toole T.E. Katagiri Y. Faull R.J. Peter K. Tamura R. Quaranta V. Loftus J.C. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Cell Biol. 1994; 124: 1047-1059Crossref PubMed Scopus (581) Google Scholar, 6Chen Y.-P. O'Toole T.E. Shipley T. Forsyth J. LaFlamme S.E. Yamada K.M. Shattil S.J. Ginsberg M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 18307-18310Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) or by certain antibodies, which recognize ligand-induced binding site epitopes within αIIbβ3 (7Frelinger III, A.L. Du X. Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17106-17111Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). Binding of fibrinogen to the αIIbβ3-integrin induces outside-in signaling in platelets, comprising the activation of protein tyrosine kinases and protein tyrosine phosphatases, and the translocation of diverse kinases and small GTP-binding proteins to the cytoskeleton (8Clark E.A. Shattil S.J. Brugge J.S. Trends Biochem. Sci. 1994; 19: 464-469Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (154) Google Scholar, 9Fox J.E.B. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1993; 344: 175-185Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar, 10Ezumi Y. Takayama H. Okuma M. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 11927-11934Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (80) Google Scholar, 11Dash D. Aepfelbacher M. Siess W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 17321-17326Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (55) Google Scholar). The heterodimer αIIbβ3 complex in resting platelets is also a major Ca2+-binding site, which accounts for >90% of the high affinity Ca2+ binding of the external platelet surface membrane (12Brass L.F. Shattil S.J. J. Clin. Invest. 1984; 73: 626-632Crossref PubMed Scopus (40) Google Scholar). Platelets contain two Ca2+-binding sites per αIIbβ3-integrin. Recent studies have indicated that one Ca2+-binding site is located at the RGD-binding segment of β3 (residues 118-131); the other is probably on the fibrinogen γ-chain binding region of αIIb (residues 294-314) (13D'Souza S.E. Haas T.A. Piotrowicz R.S. Byers-Ward V. McGrath D.E. Soule H.R. Cierniewski C. Plow E.F. Smith J.W. Cell. 1994; 79: 659-667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar). The occupancy of these cation-binding sites by Ca2+ is apparently required to maintain the αIIbβ3 complex (14Kunicki T.J. Pidard D. Rosa J.-P. Nurden A.T. Blood. 1981; 58: 268-278Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 15Hagen I. Bjerrum O.J. Gogstad G. Korsmo R. Solum N.O. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 701: 1-6Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 16Gogstad G.O. Hagen I. Krutnes M.B. Solum N.O. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1982; 689: 21-30Crossref PubMed Scopus (25) Google Scholar, 17Brass L.F. Shattil S.J. Kunicki T.J. Bennett J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 7875-7881Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). After incubation of platelets with EGTA or EDTA to chelate Ca2+ from the platelet surface membrane, the binding of monoclonal antibodies directed to epitopes of the αIIbβ3 complex (but not to the single αIIb or β3 glycoproteins) is drastically reduced or abolished (17Brass L.F. Shattil S.J. Kunicki T.J. Bennett J.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 7875-7881Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 18Pidard D. Didry D. Kunicki T.J. Nurden A.T. Blood. 1986; 67: 604-611Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 19Nomura S. Nagata H. Oda K. Kokawa T. Yasunaga K. Thromb. Res. 1987; 47: 47-58Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (45) Google Scholar, 20Gachet C. Hanau D. Spehner D. Brisson C. Garaud J.-C. Schmitt D.A. Ohlmann P. Cazenave P. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 1021-1030Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar). It seems, therefore, that chelation of Ca2+ from the high affinity binding sites by EGTA or EDTA leads to the dissociation of the αIIbβ3 complex. These platelets are unable to bind fibrinogen and to aggregate (21Zucker M.B. Grant R.A. Blood. 1978; 52: 505-514Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 22Peerschke E.I. Grant R.A. Zucker M.B. Br. J. Haematol. 1980; 46: 247-256Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar), and they show, furthermore, a reduced rate of Ca2+-influx across the plasma membrane of unstimulated platelets (23Brass L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 2231-2236Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). A better understanding of the mechanisms of action of EGTA and EDTA on platelets might be of medical relevance, since platelets play a central role in the pathogenesis of various cardiovascular diseases (24Siess W. Adv. Exp. Med. Biol. 1990; 273: 119-128Crossref PubMed Scopus (5) Google Scholar), and chelation therapy, a program of repeated intravenous administration of EDTA, is being used in patients suffering from coronary, peripheral, and cerebral vascular disorders (25Chappell L.T. Stahl J.P. J. Adv. Med. 1993; 6: 139-160Google Scholar, 26Van Rij A.M. Solomon C. Packer S.G.K. Hopkins W.G. Circulation. 1994; 90: 1194-1199Crossref PubMed Scopus (86) Google Scholar). Based on previous studies of αIIbβ3-integrin-mediated outside-in signaling, we wondered whether the dissociation of the αIIbβ3 complex might also be sensed by the cell interior. It is possible that the cytoplasmic domains of αIIbβ3 bind, directly or indirectly, signal transduction proteins, such as specific tyrosine kinases and phosphatases. In fact, β1- and β3-integrins have been suggested to associate directly with the focal adhesion kinase pp125FAK (27Schaller M.D. Parsons J.T. Curr. We observed in the present study that the dissociation of the αIIbβ3-integrin is associated with a profound stimulation of the tyrosine kinase pp72syk but not the focal adhesion kinase pp125FAK and is paralleled by a distinct increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of 62-, 68-, and 130-kDa proteins in intact platelets. Remarkably, the profound activation of pp72syk, induced by dissociation of the integrin, did not cause any sign of physiological platelet activation. Platelet suspensions (0.6 ml) were lysed in an equal volume of 2× radioimmunoprecipitation buffer (2 × RIPA, pH 7.4: 2% Triton X-100, 2 mM EGTA, 100 mM HEPES, 150 mM NaCl, 2 mM phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride, 2 mM sodium orthovanadate, 200 μg/ml leupeptin, and 200 μg/ml aprotinin) for 30 min on ice. The lysates were clarified by centrifugation at 15,600 × g for 10 min at 4°C. The supernatant (1.2 ml) was incubated with agarose conjugates of 8 μg anti-pp72syk-IgG2α and subsequently of 20 μg anti-pp125FAK-IgG1 at 4°C for 2 or 12 h. The immunoprecipitate was pelleted by centrifugation (15,600 × g for 10 min at 4°C) and washed three times with ice-cold RIPA buffer (1 ml), once with 10 mM HEPES, 500 mM NaCl (pH 8.0), and once with HEPES 10 mM (pH 8.0). Immunoprecipitates were incubated for 3 min at 95°C in 100 μl of sample buffer. For kinase assays, pp72syk immunoprecipitates were incubated with 50 μl of kinase assay buffer (100 mM HEPES, pH 8, 0.1 μM ATP, 0.01 mM sodium orthovanadate, 50 mM Mg acetate, and 150 mM NaCl) for 2 or 10 min at 25°C. The reaction was stopped by the addition of 50 μl of 2× sample buffer containing 30 mM EDTA and incubation for 3 min at 95°C. We found that the increase of protein tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, p130, and pp72syk evoked by EGTA and EDTA was temperature dependent. The stimulation was only observed when platelets were incubated with EGTA or EDTA at 37°C and furthermore found when platelets were incubated in the absence of continuous stirring (Fig. 3). Tyrosine phosphorylation did not increase when platelets were incubated with EGTA or EDTA at room temperature (Fig. 2, lanes 2 and 6; Fig. 3, lanes 1 and 2). The stimulation of tyrosine phosphorylation of pp72syk, p62, p68, and p130 showed similar concentration-response-curves (Fig. 3) and was dependent on the time of incubation. No increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of pp72syk, p62, p68, and p130 was observed when platelets were incubated with EGTA for 5 min. Tyrosine phosphorylation increased subsequently and reached maximal levels between 20 and 40 min of platelet incubation with EGTA (Fig. 4). The increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of pp72syk was more pronounced than the increase of the other proteins. EGTA did not increase tyrosine phosphorylation of the focal adhesion kinase pp125FAK, indicating that in contrast to pp72syk, this tyrosine kinase was not activated by EGTA. When platelets were incubated in the presence of EGTA (2 mM) at 21°C in buffers with pH values ranging from 6.5 to 8.5, stimulation of protein tyrosine phosphorylation was only observed at alkaline pH (>8.0); at pH 8.5 it was 158, 307, 182, and 458% of control for p62, p68, p130, and pp72syk, respectively. Stimulation of pp72syk tyrosine phosphorylation was also higher when platelets were incubated at 37°C with EGTA at pH 8.5 than at pH 6.5 (data not shown). To find out whether EGTA stimulated the enzymatic activity of pp72syk in intact platelets, immunoprecipitation kinase assays were carried out. Anti-pp72syk immunoprecipitates were incubated in kinase buffer with ATP for 2 and 10 min, and autophosphorylation of pp72syk was measured by anti-phosphotyrosine immunoblot. As shown in Fig. 6, EGTA treatment of platelets stimulated the kinase activity of pp72syk. The stimulation was almost as pronounced as after platelet stimulation with thrombin. Autophosphorylation of pp72syk in immunoprecipitation kinase assays increased 2.4 ± 0.8-fold after treatment with EGTA (2 mM for 20 min) and 3 ± 0.45-fold after treatment with thrombin (1 unit/ml for 10 s; mean ± S.D.; n = 6). Suspensions of washed control platelets (lanes 1 and 2) or thrombasthenic platelets (lanes 3 and 4) were incubated as indicated.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) Studies on the regulation of stimulation of pp72syk, p62, p68, and p130 tyrosine phosphorylation induced by EGTA indicated that the stimulation of pp72syk tyrosine phosphorylation was quite insensitive against various inhibitors (the cAMP- and cGMP-increasing drugs iloprost and SIN-1, respectively, and the cytosolic Ca2+ chelator BAPTA-AM), whereas tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, and p130 was strongly reduced and often was lower than in control platelets. Preincubation (2 min) of platelets with iloprost (100 nM) or SIN-1 (500 μM), which increased the levels of platelet cAMP and cGMP, respectively, did not affect the stimulation of pp72syk tyrosine phosphorylation evoked by EGTA (5 mM for 20 min), but it reduced pp72syk tyrosine phosphorylation stimulated by thrombin (0.1 units for 10 s); however, the stimulation of p62, p68, and p130 evoked by EGTA was reduced to control levels by iloprost and SIN-1 (data not shown). The incubation of platelets with BAPTA-AM inhibited only slightly the increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of pp72syk but suppressed the stimulation of p62, p68, and p130 tyrosine phosphorylation evoked by EGTA. Incubation of platelets with BAPTA-AM (20 μM) for 20 min reduced the EGTA (2 mM)-induced stimulation of pp72syk tyrosine phosphorylation from 5.7 ± 2.5 to 4.3 ± 3.7-fold but strongly suppressed the EGTA-induced stimulation of tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, and p130 from 2.0 ± 0.3 to 0.3 ± 0.2, 3.0 ± 0.4 to 0.5 ± 0.4, and 1.5 ± 0.2 to 0.4 ± 0.1-fold, respectively (mean ± S.D.; n = 3-5; see also Figs. 2, lanes 4 and 11, and 7, lanes 2 and 4). These data indicate that the activation of pp72syk induced by EGTA-mediated dissociation of the αIIbβ3 complex is quite independent of cytosolic Ca2+, and moreover is insensitive to inhibition by cAMP or cGMP, suggesting a close coupling of αIIbβ3-integrin and pp72syk. The present study indicates that the dissociation of the αIIbβ3-integrin by EGTA induces activation of the tyrosine kinase pp72syk but not pp125FAK. Activation of pp72syk was accompanied by an increased tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, and p130. It was surprising to find that the profound activation of pp72syk induced by EGTA did not lead to a physiological platelet response. Previously, a rapid and transient activation of pp72syk has been observed after platelet stimulation by a wide range of platelet stimuli, suggesting a role of pp72syk in early platelet signal transduction (32Taniguchi T. The concomitant stimulation of other signal transduction pathways (46Hartwig J.H. Bokoch G.M. Carpenter C.L. Janmey P.A. Taylor L.A. Toker A. Stossel T.P. Cell. 1995; 82: 643-653Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (613) Google Scholar) might be necessary which leads to the increase of actin polymerization and reorganization of the actin-rich cytoskeleton during shape change. These cytoskeletal changes are not found after treatment with EGTA (data not shown). Previously, we found that shape change induced by the partial thrombin receptor agonist YFLLRNP was associated with an increased tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, and p130 (37Negrescu E.V. de Quintana K.L. Siess W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1057-1061Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). Although the degree of tyrosine phosphorylation of p68 and p130 induced by EGTA was less than after stimuli (YFLLRNP and EDTA) that induced shape change, the increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of pp72syk was more pronounced after EGTA treatment. It is not known but it is possible that p62, p68, and p130 are substrates of pp72syk in intact platelets. The discrepancy of a higher degree of pp72syk activation and less tyrosine phosphorylation of p68 and p130 after treatment with EGTA as compared to YFLLRNP might be explained either by activation of further tyrosine kinases or translocation of pp72syk to the cytoskeleton during platelet shape change. In that location, active pp72syk might more efficiently phosphorylate the putative polypeptide substrates p62, p68, and p130, which are present in the cytoskeleton (37Negrescu E.V. de Quintana K.L. Siess W. J. Biol. Chem. 1995; 270: 1057-1061Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (62) Google Scholar). The activation of pp72syk and the increase of protein tyrosine phosphorylation induced by EGTA were mediated by the αIIbβ3. (a) It was not observed in thrombasthenic platelets, which lack the αIIbβ3-integrin. (b) It was only found under incubation conditions (time, temperature, and pH) that dissociate the αIIbβ3-integrin (14Kunicki T.J. Pidard D. Rosa J.-P. Nurden A.T. Interestingly, only complex-specific antibodies (and not antibodies directed against αIIb or β3) have been reported to stabilize the αIIbβ3-integrin; EGTA and EDTA were then unable to induce dissociation of the complex (20Gachet C. Hanau D. Spehner D. Brisson C. Garaud J.-C. Schmitt D.A. Ohlmann P. Cazenave P. J. Cell Biol. 1993; 120: 1021-1030Crossref PubMed Scopus (44) Google Scholar, 23Brass L.F. J. Biol. Chem. 1983; 258: 12582-12586Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). There are some similarities between Ca2+ chelators and fibrinogen-receptor ligands concerning the effect on the αIIbβ3-integrin. Both binding of ligands such as RGD-peptides to the receptor and chelation of cations from the receptor in the absence of ligand expose ligand-induced binding sites epitopes (7Frelinger III, A.L. Du X. Plow E.F. Ginsberg M.H. J. Biol. Chem. 1991; 266: 17106-17111Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 47Ginsberg M.H. Lightsey A.L. Kunicki T.J. Kaufman A. Marguerie G.A. Plow E.F. J. Clin. Invest. 1986; 78: 1103-1111Crossref PubMed Scopus (112) Google Scholar). The αIIbβ3-integrin has two Ca2+-binding sites: one presumably at the EF-hand Ca2+-binding motif of αIIb (residues 296-306), the other at β3 (residues 118-131) (13D'Souza S.E. Haas T.A. Piotrowicz R.S. Byers-Ward V. McGrath D.E. Soule H.R. Cierniewski C. Plow E.F. Smith J.W. Cell. 1994; 79: 659-667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar). Interestingly, not only Ca2+ chelators but also ligand binding to the αIIbβ3-integrin apparently removes these cations. It has been demonstrated that RGD-containing ligands bound to the same cation-binding segment of β3 (residues 118-131); this binding was followed by displacement of the cation (13D'Souza S.E. Haas T.A. Piotrowicz R.S. Byers-Ward V. McGrath D.E. Soule H.R. Cierniewski C. Plow E.F. Smith J.W. Cell. 1994; 79: 659-667Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (204) Google Scholar). RGDS, in our study, did not stimulate pp72syk kinase and protein tyrosine phosphorylation (data not shown). We conclude that the RGD-ligand-induced displacement of cations and the associated conformational change of the αIIbβ3-integrin is not sufficient to activate pp72syk. Either a dissociation of the αIIbβ3-integrin (as induced by EGTA) or a second signal, such as a further conformational change of the complex (as induced by fibrinogen binding), is required. It has been demonstrated that the N-terminal noncatalytic domain of pp125FAK can bind directly to the cytoplasmic tail of the β1-integrin in vitro (48Schaller M.D. Otey C.A. Hildebrand J.D. Parsons J.T. J. Cell Biol. 1995; 130: 1181-1187Crossref PubMed Scopus (556) Google Scholar). It is not known whether pp125FAK is bound to the β3-integrin in intact platelets. Our results show that dissociation of the αIIbβ3-integrin did not cause activation of pp125FAK, which has been functionally linked to the formation of focal adhesions (27Schaller M.D. Parsons J.T. Curr. Biol. 1994; 6: 705-710Crossref Scopus (495) Google Scholar). It is remarkable that the stimulation of tyrosine phosphorylation of pp72syk evoked by EGTA was quite insensitive to inhibition by various drugs, namely the cytosolic Ca2+ chelator BAPTA-AM and the cAMP- and cGMP-elevating drugs iloprost and SIN-1, respectively. All of these substances, however, efficiently reduced the increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, and p130 induced by EGTA. It seems, therefore, that the αIIbβ3-integrin and pp72syk are, functionally, closely coupled in intact platelets: the interaction of the αIIbβ3-integrin with pp72syk is not accessible to these drugs, in contrast to the phosphorylation of the putative polypeptide substrates by the active pp72syk. How is pp72syk activated by αIIbβ3-integrin dissociation? Two models can be considered. (a) The dissociation of the complex enables the now free cytoplasmic domains of αIIb or β3 to interact indirectly or directly with pp72syk, thereby activating the enzyme. (B) The αIIbβ3 complex in resting platelets might be bound to an active protein tyrosine phosphatase, which dephosphorylates pp72syk, thereby inhibiting its enzymatic activity. Dissociation of the complex leads to the loss of active protein tyrosine phosphatase and, hence, to an increase of pp72syk tyrosine phosphorylation and activity. Collectively, we have observed in the present study that the dissociation of the αIIbβ3-integrin was associated with a profound stimulation of the tyrosine kinase pp72syk but not the focal adhesion kinase pp125FAK and was paralleled by a distinct increase of tyrosine phosphorylation of p62, p68, and p130 in intact platelets. Remarkably, the profound activation of pp72syk induced by αIIbβ3-integrin dissociation did not cause any sign of physiological platelet activation. We thank U. Wielert for expert technical assistance, E. Bretzke for secretarial help, and F. Haag for the skillful photographic reproduction of the autoradiographs. We thank Dr. Carl M. Kirchmaier (Blutspendedienst Hessen, Frankfurt, Germany) for his help in obtaining thrombasthenic platelets.

Calcium vector protein target (CaVPT), a 26-kDa endogenous target of calcium vector protein from Amphioxus (CaVP), contains three distinct regions: a N-terminal Pro-Ala-Lys-rich motif, segment 36-50 displaying sequence similarity to the calmodulin-binding site in neuromodulin and neurogranin where they are designated as the IQ domain; and two immunoglobulin-like folds. The phosphorylation by protein kinase C of Ser-43 in the IQ domain drastically decreases the affinity of CaVPT for CaVP and CaVP protects CaVPT from phosphorylation. Phosphorylation by the catalytic subunit of cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase has a similar effect, but in addition to Ser-43 four other phosphorylated sites were identified. Removal of the Pro-Ala-Lys-rich region and the IQ domain in CaVPT by trypsin leads to the loss of binding to CaVP, whereas the chymotryptic fragment, containing these regions and first immunoglobulin-like domain, retained the ability to interact with CaVP. A synthetic IQ domain alone interacts strongly with calmodulin, but not with CaVP. Two main conclusions can be drawn from this study: 1) the regulation of interaction between CaVP and CaVPT is very similar to the mechanism observed in the complex between neuromodulin or neurogranin and calmodulin; 2) in spite of this similarity the entire CaVP-binding site is not restricted to the IQ domain; in addition the Pro-Ala-Lys-rich motif may be necessary for high affinity binding to CaVP. The phosphorylation by protein kinase C of Ser-43 in the IQ domain drastically decreases the affinity of CaVPT for CaVP and CaVP protects CaVPT from phosphorylation. Phosphorylation by the catalytic subunit of cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase has a similar effect, but in addition to Ser-43 four other phosphorylated sites were identified. Removal of the Pro-Ala-Lys-rich region and the IQ domain in CaVPT by trypsin leads to the loss of binding to CaVP, whereas the chymotryptic fragment, containing these regions and first immunoglobulin-like domain, retained the ability to interact with CaVP. A synthetic IQ domain alone interacts strongly with calmodulin, but not with CaVP. Two main conclusions can be drawn from this study: 1) the regulation of interaction between CaVP and CaVPT is very similar to the mechanism observed in the complex between neuromodulin or neurogranin and calmodulin; 2) in spite of this similarity the entire CaVP-binding site is not restricted to the IQ domain; in addition the Pro-Ala-Lys-rich motif may be necessary for high affinity binding to CaVP. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 13173-13178Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 1986; 16Head J.F. Perry S.V. Biochem. J. 1974; 137: 145-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar and Perry, 1974). In spite of about 30% of sequence similarity to troponin C and CaM, CaVP does not substitute for the latter proteins in functional assays and bona fide CaM and troponin C are present in Amphioxus (30Takagi T. Petrova T. Comte M. Kuster T. Heizmann C.W. Cox J.A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1994; 221: 537-546Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar et al., 1994), suggesting that CaVP assumes a particular function in the muscle of this higher invertebrate. Moreover, the only known endogenous target of CaVP is CaVPT, a unique 26-kDa protein displaying the following domain structure: 1) segment 1-23, a Pro-Ala-Lys-rich repetitive motif at the N terminus; 2) segment 36-50 displaying sequence similarity to CaM-binding sites in neuromodulin and neurogranin (Alexander et al., 1988; 3Apel E.D. Byford M.F. Au D. Walsh K. Storm D. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 2330-2335Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar et al., 1990; Baudier et al., 1991) where they are designated as the IQ domains; 3) segment 63-243 composed of two Ig-folds, structural motifs also found in myosin light chain kinase (24Olson N.J. Pearson R.B. Needleman D.S. Hurwitz M.Y. Kemp B.E. Means A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2284-2288Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar et al., 1990), telokin (18Ito M. Dabrowska R. Guerreiro Jr., V. Hartshorne D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13971-13974Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1989), C-protein (14Fürst D.O. Vinkemeier U. Weber K. J. Cell Sci. 1992; 102: 769-778PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1992), twitchin (5Benian G.M. Kiff J.E. Neckelmann N. Moerman D.G. Waterston R.H. Nature. 1989; 342: 45-50Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar et al., 1989), and titin (19Labeit S. Gautel M. Lakey A. Trinick J. EMBO J. 1990; 11: 1711-1716Crossref Scopus (277) Google Scholar et al., 1990), proteins believed to be involved in homotypic interactions as well as in the interaction with myosin. At present the role of CaVPT is not well established, although recent data indicate that it interacts with a paramyosin-like protein and thus may participate in regulation of thick filament dynamics (26Petrova T.V. Comte M. Takagi T. Cox J.A. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 312-318Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar et al., 1995b).Our previous study indicated that while the complex CaVP-CaVPT possesses a rather rigid structure and does not display pronounced interactive properties, CaVP and CaVPT have characteristics of highly dynamic proteins (27Petrova T.V. Comte M. Takagi T. Cox J.A. Ninth International Symposium on Calcium-binding Proteins and Calcium functions in Health and Disease. Airlie, VAApril 29 to May 3,1995Google Scholar et al., 1995a). This allowed us to hypothesize that the complex represents a non-interactive end product and that CaVPT itself is the relay protein toward the unknown cellular response element. Under physiological conditions the affinity of CaVP for CaVPT is 80-fold higher in the presence of Ca2+, but Ca2+ removal does not lead to dissociation. In search of a physiological mechanism of CaVP-CaVPT dissociation we have studied the effect of phosphorylation by PKA and PKC on the interactive properties of CaVPT, in analogy with the dissociation mechanism proposed for neuromodulin/neurogranin and CaM (Apel et al., 1990; Baudier et al., 1991). We have also investigated by means of controlled proteolysis the domain structure of CaVPT and the interactive properties of the individual domains. Finally, we studied the interaction of CaVP with a synthetic peptide IQ comprising the IQ domain of CaVPT, in order to evaluate whether this sequence represents the CaVP-binding site, as it was suggested earlier (29Takagi T. Cox J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 19721-19727Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and Cox, 1991).DISCUSSIONThe Ig-fold is a common structural motif found in many intracellular muscle proteins, such as the giant protein titin (20Labeit S. Kolmerer B. Science. 1995; 270: 293-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (984) Google Scholar and Kolmerer, 1995), myosin light chain kinase (Olson et al., 1990), C-protein (Fürst et al., 1992), M-protein (22Noguchi J. Yanagisawa M. Imamura M. Kasuya Y. Sakurai T. Tanaka T. Masaki T. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 20302-20310Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1992), myomesin (23Obermann W.M.J. Plessmann U. Weber K. Fürst D.O. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 233: 110-115Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar et al., 1995), H-protein (32Vaughan K.T. Weber F.E. Einheber S. Fishman D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 3670-3676Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1993) etc. It is composed of about 100 amino acids that form a β-barrel consisting of 8 β strands (17Holden H.M. Ito M. Hartshorne D.J. Rayment I. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 227: 840-851Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar et al., 1992; 25Pfuhl M. Gautel M. Politou A.S. Joseph C. Pastore A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1995; 6: 48-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar et al., 1995). Although the number of Ig-folds per protein varies from 112 copies in titin (Labeit and Kolmerer, 1995) to only 1 in the gizzard smooth muscle component telokin (Ito et al., 1989), all intracellular Ig-fold containing proteins are thought to be implicated in the regulation of myosin activity and assembly of thick filaments. CaVPT from muscle of Amphioxus is one of the smallest members of this family: it contains only two Ig-folds that account for 80% of its sequence (Fig. 9a). Residues 36-50 preceding the Ig-folds, display a high degree of sequence similarity to the CaM-binding domains of neuromodulin and neurogranin (Fig. 9b), as it was pointed by 8Cheney R.E. Espreafico E.M. Larson R.E. Mooseker M.S. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115 (abstr.): 432Google Scholar et al. (1991). Takagi and Cox (1991) have demonstrated that CaVPT can bind to CaM but in vivo it rather forms a strong complex with CaVP, a particular Ca2+-binding protein of the EF-hand superfamily. Until now CaVPT represents a unique example where an intracellular Ig-fold protein is associated with a Ca2+-binding component.Neuromodulin and neurogranin constitute a separate group within the family of CaM-binding proteins due to their ability to fix CaM with almost equal and relatively low affinity in the absence as in the presence of Ca2+ (1Alexander K.A. Cimler B.M. Meier K.E. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6108-6113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1987; Baudier et al., 1991). The regulation of their interaction with CaM is achieved through the phosphorylation by PKC of a serine residue in the CaM-binding domain, referred to as the IQ domain (Apel et al., 1990; Baudier et al, 1991). Similar IQ motifs, often in numerous copies, have also been identified in many unconventional myosins where they serve to anchor CaM (13Espreafico E.M. Cheney R.E. Matteoli M. Nascimento A. De Camilli P.V. Larson R.E. Mooseker M.S. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 6: 1541-1557Crossref Scopus (306) Google Scholar et al., 1992; reviewed by 36Wolenski J.S. Trends Cell Biol. 1995; 5: 310-316Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar (1995)). Recently, it was shown that the ATPase activity of p68 RNA helicase, the protein possessing one IQ motif, is modulated by phosphorylation and calmodulin binding (7Buelt M.K. Glidden B.J. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 29367-29370Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1994). In this study we have investigated how the interaction of CaVP and CaVPT is regulated by phosphorylation of the IQ domain and which of the individual domains of CaVPT contribute to the formation of the CaVP-binding site.Phosphorylation of CaVPTOf four potential phosphorylation sites for PKC in CaVPT, namely Ser-43, Ser-145, Thr-164, and Thr-239, only Ser-43 situated in the IQ domain can be phosphorylated in vitro. The phosphorylation of Ser-43 drastically decreases the affinity of CaVPT for CaVP and a 3-fold excess of CaVP protects CaVPT from phosphorylation. These data underline the universality of the IQ domain as a module for the PKC-regulated interaction with Ca2+-binding proteins in otherwise very different protein systems. The biological consequence of this phosphorylation likely varies from one protein to another as they show very little sequence homology except for the IQ domain. It was proposed that the phosphorylation of neuromodulin and neurogranin leads to an increase of the “local” concentration of CaM and to the activation of CaM-regulated processes (Alexander et al., 1987). However, in the case of the CaVP/CaVPT system, we rather suggest that the phosphorylation is necessary to maintain CaVPT in its free state. Indeed, free CaVPT but not the complex was found to interact with the 106-kDa protein from Amphioxus muscle (Petrova et al., 1995b).With PROSITE, a dictionary of post-translational modification sites (Geneva University Hospital and University of Geneva, Geneva, Switzerland), no consensus sequence for PKA can be detected in CaVPT. It is known, however, that many well established substrates of PKA do not possess a canonical phosphorylation site RRxS (34Walsh D.A. Van Patten S.M. FASEB J. 1994; 8: 1227-1236Crossref PubMed Scopus (214) Google Scholar and Van Patten, 1994). Our data clearly show that CaVPT can be phosphorylated by the catalytic subunit of PKA at multiple sites, including Ser-43, and that the phosphorylation is prevented by CaVP. Moreover, these results provide an interesting example of allosteric propagation of a conformational change in CaVPT induced by CaVP: four out of the five phosphorylation sites are located in the second Ig-fold (Fig. 9a), i.e. far away from the suggested CaVP-binding site, yet in the complex CaVP-CaVPT these sites cannot be phosphorylated. Likewise we previously observed a strong decrease in the reactivity of two thiols located in the second Ig-fold of CaVPT upon formation of the complex with CaVP (Petrova et al., 1995a). We suggest, therefore, that the binding of CaVP provokes an allosteric re-arrangement in the structure of CaVPT which propagates from the N to the C terminus of the protein. Interestingly, a similar model of ligand-induced conformational changes may be proposed for C-CAM1, an epithelial cell adhesion molecule of the immunoglobulin superfamily. Binding of CaM to the cytoplasmic domain of C-CAM1, situated at the C terminus of the molecule, causes a down-regulation of the homophilic self-association of C-CAM1 which is thought to mediate cell-cell adhesion (12Edlund M. Blikstad I. Öbrink B. J. Biol. Chem. 1996; 271: 1393-1399Abstract Full Text Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (65) Google Scholar et al., 1996).Domain Structure of CaVPT and CaVP-binding SiteThe phosphorylation of Ser-43 within the IQ motif is prevented by CaVP suggesting that the phosphorylation occurs in the CaVP-binding domain. Moreover, the phosphorylation of Ser-43 efficiently inhibits the interaction between CaVPT and CaVP. The question arises whether the IQ domain alone represents an entire CaVP-binding site. The synthetic IQ peptide, which comprises residues 36-50 of CaVPT, revealed to be a good target for CaM but, surprisingly, interacted only weakly with CaVP. In the case of the entire protein the situation is inverse: the affinity of CaVP for intact CaVPT exceeds significantly that of CaM (Cox, 1986). This apparent contradiction can be resolved by the assumption that the fully potential CaVP-binding site includes an additional region(s) of CaVPT. A parallel can be drawn with the γ-subunit of phosphorylase kinase, where the CaM-binding site is composed of two noncontiguous subdomains (10Dasgupta M. Honeycutt T. Blumenthal D.K. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 17156-17163Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1989). The binding properties of the proteolytic fragments point to the importance of the region 1-50 of CaVPT, including, in addition to the IQ domain, the Pro-Ala-Lys-rich region (Fig. 9a). Pro-rich domains were found to play a significant role in protein-protein interactions (reviewed by 35Williamson M.P. Biochem. J. 1994; 297: 249-260Crossref PubMed Scopus (834) Google Scholar (1994)). In further studies concerning the exact boundaries of the CaVP-binding site, our working hypothesis is that both the Pro-Ala-Lys-rich domain and the IQ motif participate in its formation. Cox J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 19721-19727Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and Cox, 1991). Calcium vector protein (CaVP) 1The abbreviations used are: CaVPcalcium vector proteinCaVPTcalcium vector protein targetCaMcalmodulinIQ peptidesynthetic peptide corresponding to the residues 33-61 of CaVPTDTTdithiothreitolHPLChigh pressure liquid chromatographyPKAcyclic AMP-dependent protein kinasePKCprotein kinase CIg-foldimmunoglobulin-like foldC1-186chymotryptic fragment corresponding to residues 1-186 of CaVPTT51-243tryptic fragment corresponding to residues 51-243 of CaVPTPAGEpolyacrylamide gel electrophoresisCAPS3-(cyclohexylamino)-1-propanesulfonateMES4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid. and its endogenous target (CaVPT) are present in muscle of Amphioxus at unusually high concentration, namely 50 to 100 μM in terms of intracellular water, comparable to that of the abundant muscle component troponin C (9Cox J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 13173-13178Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 1986; 16Head J.F. Perry S.V. Biochem. J. 1974; 137: 145-154Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar and Perry, 1974). In spite of about 30% of sequence similarity to troponin C and CaM, CaVP does not substitute for the latter proteins in functional assays and bona fide CaM and troponin C are present in Amphioxus (30Takagi T. Petrova T. Comte M. Kuster T. Heizmann C.W. Cox J.A. Eur. J. Biochem. 1994; 221: 537-546Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar et al., 1994), suggesting that CaVP assumes a particular function in the muscle of this higher invertebrate. Moreover, the only known endogenous target of CaVP is CaVPT, a unique 26-kDa protein displaying the following domain structure: 1) segment 1-23, a Pro-Ala-Lys-rich repetitive motif at the N terminus; 2) segment 36-50 displaying sequence similarity to CaM-binding sites in neuromodulin and neurogranin (Alexander et al., 1988; 3Apel E.D. Byford M.F. Au D. Walsh K. Storm D. Biochemistry. 1990; 29: 2330-2335Crossref PubMed Scopus (99) Google Scholar et al., 1990; Baudier et al., 1991) where they are designated as the IQ domains; 3) segment 63-243 composed of two Ig-folds, structural motifs also found in myosin light chain kinase (24Olson N.J. Pearson R.B. Needleman D.S. Hurwitz M.Y. Kemp B.E. Means A.R. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 2284-2288Crossref PubMed Scopus (173) Google Scholar et al., 1990), telokin (18Ito M. Dabrowska R. Guerreiro Jr., V. Hartshorne D.J. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 13971-13974Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1989), C-protein (14Fürst D.O. Vinkemeier U. Weber K. J. Cell Sci. 1992; 102: 769-778PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1992), twitchin (5Benian G.M. Kiff J.E. Neckelmann N. Moerman D.G. Waterston R.H. Nature. 1989; 342: 45-50Crossref PubMed Scopus (262) Google Scholar et al., 1989), and titin (19Labeit S. Gautel M. Lakey A. Trinick J. EMBO J. 1990; 11: 1711-1716Crossref Scopus (277) Google Scholar et al., 1990), proteins believed to be involved in homotypic interactions as well as in the interaction with myosin. At present the role of CaVPT is not well established, although recent data indicate that it interacts with a paramyosin-like protein and thus may participate in regulation of thick filament dynamics (26Petrova T.V. Comte M. Takagi T. Cox J.A. Biochemistry. 1995; 34: 312-318Crossref PubMed Scopus (11) Google Scholar et al., 1995b). calcium vector protein calcium vector protein target calmodulin synthetic peptide corresponding to the residues 33-61 of CaVPT dithiothreitol high pressure liquid chromatography cyclic AMP-dependent protein kinase protein kinase C immunoglobulin-like fold chymotryptic fragment corresponding to residues 1-186 of CaVPT tryptic fragment corresponding to residues 51-243 of CaVPT polyacrylamide gel electrophoresis 3-(cyclohexylamino)-1-propanesulfonate 4-morpholineethanesulfonic acid. Our previous study indicated that while the complex CaVP-CaVPT possesses a rather rigid structure and does not display pronounced interactive properties, CaVP and CaVPT have characteristics of highly dynamic proteins (27Petrova T.V. Comte M. Takagi T. Cox J.A. Ninth International Symposium on Calcium-binding Proteins and Calcium functions in Health and Disease. Airlie, VAApril 29 to May 3,1995Google Scholar et al., 1995a). This allowed us to hypothesize that the complex represents a non-interactive end product and that CaVPT itself is the relay protein toward the unknown cellular response element. Under physiological conditions the affinity of CaVP for CaVPT is 80-fold higher in the presence of Ca2+, but Ca2+ removal does not lead to dissociation. In search of a physiological mechanism of CaVP-CaVPT dissociation we have studied the effect of phosphorylation by PKA and PKC on the interactive properties of CaVPT, in analogy with the dissociation mechanism proposed for neuromodulin/neurogranin and CaM (Apel et al., 1990; Baudier et al., 1991). We have also investigated by means of controlled proteolysis the domain structure of CaVPT and the interactive properties of the individual domains. Finally, we studied the interaction of CaVP with a synthetic peptide IQ comprising the IQ domain of CaVPT, in order to evaluate whether this sequence represents the CaVP-binding site, as it was suggested earlier (29Takagi T. Cox J.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 19721-19727Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar and Cox, 1991). DISCUSSIONThe Ig-fold is a common structural motif found in many intracellular muscle proteins, such as the giant protein titin (20Labeit S. Kolmerer B. Science. 1995; 270: 293-296Crossref PubMed Scopus (984) Google Scholar and Kolmerer, 1995), myosin light chain kinase (Olson et al., 1990), C-protein (Fürst et al., 1992), M-protein (22Noguchi J. Yanagisawa M. Imamura M. Kasuya Y. Sakurai T. Tanaka T. Masaki T. J. Biol. Chem. 1992; 267: 20302-20310Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1992), myomesin (23Obermann W.M.J. Plessmann U. Weber K. Fürst D.O. Eur. J. Biochem. 1995; 233: 110-115Crossref PubMed Scopus (36) Google Scholar et al., 1995), H-protein (32Vaughan K.T. Weber F.E. Einheber S. Fishman D.A. J. Biol. Chem. 1993; 268: 3670-3676Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1993) etc. It is composed of about 100 amino acids that form a β-barrel consisting of 8 β strands (17Holden H.M. Ito M. Hartshorne D.J. Rayment I. J. Mol. Biol. 1992; 227: 840-851Crossref PubMed Scopus (127) Google Scholar et al., 1992; 25Pfuhl M. Gautel M. Politou A.S. Joseph C. Pastore A. J. Biomol. NMR. 1995; 6: 48-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (16) Google Scholar et al., 1995). Although the number of Ig-folds per protein varies from 112 copies in titin (Labeit and Kolmerer, 1995) to only 1 in the gizzard smooth muscle component telokin (Ito et al., 1989), all intracellular Ig-fold containing proteins are thought to be implicated in the regulation of myosin activity and assembly of thick filaments. CaVPT from muscle of Amphioxus is one of the smallest members of this family: it contains only two Ig-folds that account for 80% of its sequence (Fig. 9a). Residues 36-50 preceding the Ig-folds, display a high degree of sequence similarity to the CaM-binding domains of neuromodulin and neurogranin (Fig. 9b), as it was pointed by 8Cheney R.E. Espreafico E.M. Larson R.E. Mooseker M.S. J. Cell Biol. 1991; 115 (abstr.): 432Google Scholar et al. (1991). Takagi and Cox (1991) have demonstrated that CaVPT can bind to CaM but in vivo it rather forms a strong complex with CaVP, a particular Ca2+-binding protein of the EF-hand superfamily. Until now CaVPT represents a unique example where an intracellular Ig-fold protein is associated with a Ca2+-binding component.Neuromodulin and neurogranin constitute a separate group within the family of CaM-binding proteins due to their ability to fix CaM with almost equal and relatively low affinity in the absence as in the presence of Ca2+ (1Alexander K.A. Cimler B.M. Meier K.E. Storm D.R. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 6108-6113Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar et al., 1987; Baudier et al., 1991). The regulation of their interaction with CaM is achieved through the phosphorylation by PKC of a serine residue in the CaM-binding domain, referred to as the IQ domain (Apel et al., 1990; Baudier et al, 1991). Similar IQ motifs, often in numerous copies, have also been identified in many unconventional myosins where they serve to anchor CaM (13Espreafico E.M. Cheney R.E. Matteoli M. Nascimento A. De Camilli P.V. Larson R.E. Mooseker M.S. J. Cell Biol. 1992; 6: 1541-1557Crossref Scopus (306) Google Scholar et al., 1992; reviewed by 36Wolenski J.S. Trends Cell Biol. 1995; 5: 310-316Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Scopus (101) Google Scholar (1995)). Recently, it was shown that the ATPase activity of p68 RNA helicase, the protein possessing one IQ motif, is modulated by phosphorylation and calmodulin binding (7

The ATP2 gene, coding for the β subunit of the mitochondrial F1-ATPase, was cloned from nine independent isolates of chemically mutagenized yeast. Seven different mutant alleles were identified. In one case the mutation occurs in the mitochondrial targeting sequence (M1I). The remaining six mutations map to the mature part of the β subunit protein and alter amino acids that are conserved in the bovine heart mitochondrial and Escherichia coli β subunit proteins. Biochemical analysis of the yeast atp2 mutants identified two different phenotypes. The G133D, P179L, and G227D mutations correlate with an assembly-defective phenotype that is characterized by the accumulation of the F1α and β subunits in large protein aggregates. Strains harboring the A192V, E222K, or R293K mutations assemble an F1 of normal size that is none-the-less catalytically inactive. The effect of the atp2 mutations was also analyzed in diploids formed by crossing the mutants to wild type yeast. Hybrid enzymes formed with β subunits containing either the G133D, E222K, or R293K mutations are compromised for steady-state ATPase activity. The display of partial dominance confirms the importance of Gly133 for structural stability and of Glu222 and Arg293 for catalytic cooperativity. The ATP2 gene, coding for the β subunit of the mitochondrial F1-ATPase, was cloned from nine independent isolates of chemically mutagenized yeast. Seven different mutant alleles were identified. In one case the mutation occurs in the mitochondrial targeting sequence (M1I). The remaining six mutations map to the mature part of the β subunit protein and alter amino acids that are conserved in the bovine heart mitochondrial and Escherichia coli β subunit proteins. Biochemical analysis of the yeast atp2 mutants identified two different phenotypes. The G133D, P179L, and G227D mutations correlate with an assembly-defective phenotype that is characterized by the accumulation of the F1α and β subunits in large protein aggregates. Strains harboring the A192V, E222K, or R293K mutations assemble an F1 of normal size that is none-the-less catalytically inactive. The effect of the atp2 mutations was also analyzed in diploids formed by crossing the mutants to wild type yeast. Hybrid enzymes formed with β subunits containing either the G133D, E222K, or R293K mutations are compromised for steady-state ATPase activity. The display of partial dominance confirms the importance of Gly133 for structural stability and of Glu222 and Arg293 for catalytic cooperativity. The F1-F0 ATP synthase (ATPase) of mitochondrial, chloroplast, and bacterial membranes catalyzes ATP synthesis coupled to respiration (1Penefsky H.S. Cross R.L. Adv. Enzymol. 1991; 64: 173-214PubMed Google Scholar, 2Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (924) Google Scholar). The enzyme is composed of a catalytic moiety, F1, attached peripherally to an integral membrane component, F0. Three types of subunits (designated a, b, and c in bacteria (3Futai M. Kanazawa H. Microbiol. Rev. 1983; 47: 285-312Crossref PubMed Google Scholar, 4Walker J.E. Saraste M. Gay N.J. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1984; 768: 164-200Crossref PubMed Scopus (371) Google Scholar)) constitute an evolutionarily conserved core F0 structure, and there is variation among species as to whether or not additional F0 subunits are present (5Collinson I.R. Runswick M.J. Buchanan S.K. Fearnley I.M. Skehel J.M. vaan Raaij M.J. Griffiths D.E. Walker J.E. Biochemistry. 1994; 33: 7971-7978Crossref PubMed Scopus (164) Google Scholar). F1 shows a remarkable degree of structural conservation, and in most organisms studied, exists as an oligomer of five different subunits with the stoichiometry α3β3γδε (1Penefsky H.S. Cross R.L. Adv. Enzymol. 1991; 64: 173-214PubMed Google Scholar, 2Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (924) Google Scholar). The x-ray structure of bovine mitochondrial F1 shows the α and β subunits alternating in a hexagonal ring, with the amino and carboxyl termini of the γ subunit located in the central core of the ring (6Abrahams J.P. Leslie A.G.W. Lutter R. Walker J.E. Nature. 1994; 370: 621-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (2751) Google Scholar). Six adenine nucleotide binding sites are located at the α/β interfaces. Three of these sites are catalytic and reside primarily in the β subunit; the other three sites are noncatalytic and are contributed mostly by residues of the α subunits (6Abrahams J.P. Leslie A.G.W. Lutter R. Walker J.E. Nature. 1994; 370: 621-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (2751) Google Scholar). The three catalytic sites interact cooperatively during enzyme turnover; this process is probably mediated by conformational changes in the F1 subunits (1Penefsky H.S. Cross R.L. Adv. Enzymol. 1991; 64: 173-214PubMed Google Scholar, 2Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (924) Google Scholar). A principal focus in F1 research is to understand the mechanistic details that underlie catalytic cooperativity. The study of mutants with defects in the F1 subunits offers a means to test the catalytic function of amino acids and to identify the residues that propagate conformational changes in the enzyme. Several excellent reviews are available that document studies performed with Escherichia coli mutants to probe the structure/function relationships in F1 (7Futai M. Noumi T. Maeda M. J. Bioenerg. Biomembr. 1988; 20: 41-58Crossref PubMed Scopus (15) Google Scholar, 8Futai M. Noumi T. Maeda M. Annu. Rev. Biochem. 1989; 58: 111-136Crossref PubMed Scopus (403) Google Scholar, 9Senior A.E. Annu. Rev. Biophys. 1990; 19: 7-41Crossref Scopus (329) Google Scholar). The mitochondrial enzyme from Saccharomyces cerevisiae is equally amenable to genetic manipulation. Moreover, the analysis of yeast F1 mutants is of particular value now that an atomic structure of the mitochondrial enzyme is available (6Abrahams J.P. Leslie A.G.W. Lutter R. Walker J.E. Nature. 1994; 370: 621-628Crossref PubMed Scopus (2751) Google Scholar). Genetic studies with yeast F1 have centered on the β subunit, which is coded for by the ATP2 gene (10Takeda M. Vassarotti A. Douglas M.G. J. Biol. Chem. 1985; 260: 15458-15465Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) in chromosome X (11Takeda M. Okushiba T. Hayashida T. Gunge N. Yeast. 1994; 10: 1531-1534Crossref PubMed Scopus (4) Google Scholar). The work reported to date has used site-directed mutagenesis to effect changes in amino acids that were previously shown to react with chemical labels (12Mueller D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1988; 263: 5634-5639Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 13Mueller D.M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1989; 164: 381-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar) and also to change residues that constitute a sequence element conserved in several nucleotide binding proteins (the P-loop) (13Mueller D.M. Biochem. Biophys. Res. Commun. 1989; 164: 381-386Crossref PubMed Scopus (6) Google Scholar, 14Mueller D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1989; 264: 16552-16556Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar, 15Shen H. Yao B. Mueller D.M. J. Biol. Chem. 1994; 269: 9424-9428Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). The present study constitutes the first report in which mutations induced chemically in the yeast β subunit gene were characterized both biochemically and genetically. Two classes of β subunit mutations were identified: those that alter catalysis without affecting the enzyme structure and those that produce defects in F1 assembly. The genotypes and sources of the mutant and wild type yeast strains used in the present study are listed in Table I. Chemically induced mutants were obtained as described (17Tzagoloff A. Dieckmann C.L. Microbiol. Rev. 1990; 54: 211-225Crossref PubMed Google Scholar). E. coli RR1 (proA leuB lacY galK xyl-5 mtl-1 ara-14 rpsL supE hsdS λ−) was the host bacterial strain for the recombinant plasmid constructions. Yeast was grown in the following media: YPD (2% glucose, 2% peptone, 1% yeast extract), YPGal (2% galactose, 2% peptone, 1% yeast extract), YEPG (3% glycerol, 2% ethanol, 2% peptone, 1% yeast extract), WO (2% glucose, 0.67% yeast nitrogen base without amino acids (Difco)). Amino acids and other growth requirements were added at a final concentration of 20 μg/ml. Biol. 1974; 88: 185-203Crossref PubMed Scopus (180) Google Scholar) was used to prepare mitochondria with the exception that zymolyase, instead of Glusulase, was used to digest the cell wall. Phenylmethylsulfonyl fluoride was added to 10 μg/ml final concentration during the cell-breaking step to minimize proteolysis. Mitochondria were suspended at 6.6 mg/ml in 10 mM Tris-HCl, pH 8.0, 2 mM EDTA, 4 mM ATP (TEA buffer) and incubated for 15 min with 0.25% Triton X-100 to extract the F1-F0 complex. The suspensions were centrifuged at 50,000 rpm in a Beckman 70.1Ti rotor for 30 min, and the resultant soluble and particulate fractions were assayed for F1 proteins by Western analysis. Step sucrose gradients were used to analyze the properties of F1 subunits in cases where the enzyme was found to be resistant to Triton X-100 extraction. Mitochondria (5 mg/ml) were permeabilized in TEA buffer by a brief exposure to sonic irradiation, and 0.2-ml samples were overlaid on a 4.8-ml discontinuous gradient of Tris-HCl, pH 7.5, buffered sucrose (20-80%, w/v). The preparation of the step gradients and the centrifugation protocol were as described (19Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4986-4990Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Linear sucrose gradients were used to evaluate the size of the F1-F0 complex in mitochondrial supernatants following Triton X-100 extraction. Solubilized protein (0.6 ml) was loaded onto a 4.4-ml 6-20% sucrose gradient prepared in 0.1% Triton X-100-supplemented TEA buffer, and the gradients were centrifuged at room temperature for 1.5 h at 55,000 rpm in a Beckman SW55Ti rotor. For all experiments, sucrose gradient fractions were collected from the bottom of the tube. The mutant atp2 genes were cloned by the method of colony hybridization (20Grunstein M. Hogness D.S. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1975; 72: 101-106Crossref Scopus (2218) Google Scholar). Following digestion of yeast genomic DNA with SphI, 7-kilobase fragments were purified from a 1% agarose gel and subcloned into a SphI-cut yeast/E. coli shuttle plasmid (either pRS316, CEN (21Sikorski R.S. Hieter P. Genetics. 1989; 122: 19-27Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) or YEp352, 2 μ (22Hill J.E. Myers A.M. Koerner T.J. Tzagoloff A. Yeast. 1986; 2: 163-167Crossref PubMed Scopus (1082) Google Scholar)). The mini-SphI libraries were used to transform E. coli, and the colonies were hybridized at 65°C with a nick-translated DNA fragment containing the entire ATP2 gene. The one-step gene replacement method (23Rothstein R.J. Methods Enzymol. 1983; 101: 202-211Crossref PubMed Scopus (2026) Google Scholar) was used to disrupt the chromosomal copy of ATP2 in the respiratory competent haploid yeasts W303-1A and W303-1B. The disruption allele (atp2::LEU2) was constructed by inserting a 2.8-kilobase BglII DNA fragment, carrying the entire LEU2 gene, into the unique BamHI site of the ATP2 reading frame. Wild type W303 strains were transformed with atp2::LEU2 on a linear DNA fragment and the transformants were screened for the stable acquisition of leucine prototrophy that correlated with the loss of respiratory function. Respiratory-deficient, Leu+ integrants of both mating types were obtained. Genetic crosses to ρ° tester strains indicated that the respiratory defect of the disruption strains (W303∇G1) was due solely to a nuclear mutation and Southern analysis verified that the gene disruption occurred at the ATP2 locus (data not shown). Genetic crosses also showed allelism between the disrupted gene in the W303∇G1 strains and atp2 present in the chemically mutagenized yeast strains. Chem. 1951; 193: 265-275Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar). ATPase activity was measured by determining the amount of inorganic phosphate released as described previously (25Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9952-9959Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar), in the absence and presence of 10 μg of oligomycin. Fritsch E.F. Sambrook J. Molecular Cloning: A Laboratory Manual. Cold Spring Harbor Laboratory, Cold Spring Harbor, NY1982Google Scholar). The dideoxy method (27Sanger F. Nicklen S. Coulson A.R. Tzagoloff A. J. Biol. Chem. 1990; 265: 9952-9959Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) to optimize resolution of the F1α and β subunit proteins. The procedure of Schmidt et al. (30Schmidt R.J. Myers A.M. Gillham N.W. Boynton F.E. Mol. Biol. Evol. 1984; 1: 317-334PubMed Google Scholar) was used for Western blotting. Chemically mutagenized yeast strains belonging to complementation group G1 (17Tzagoloff A. Dieckmann C.L. Microbiol. Rev. 1990; 54: 211-225Crossref PubMed Google Scholar) carry mutations in ATP2, the nuclear gene that codes for the β subunit of the F1-F0 ATP synthase. The mutant atp2 genes were cloned from nine G1 strains, and the mutations were sequenced (see “Experimental Procedures”). The position of these mutations in the nucleotide and protein sequences is shown in Table II. A single missense mutation was found in each of the mutants, which alters the sequence of ATP2 relative to the wild type copy present in the parental strain D273-10B/A1 (GenBank™ accession number U46215). Two of the mutations were found in more than one strain: the P179L substitution occurs in the strains C103 and E210, and the mutation E222K is present in the strains E430 and E144. 1The biochemical characteristics are described for the mutants E210 and E430 as the strains representative of the P179L and E222K mutations, respectively. The mutation in strain E700 converts the initiator methionine to isoleucine. Open table in a new tab The effect of the mutations on the assembly of F1-F0 was also studied. The manner in which the F1α and β subunits distribute between soluble and particulate fractions when wild type and mutant mitochondria are extracted with 0.25% Triton X-100 is shown in the Western blots of Fig. 2. In the wild type (D273) the α and β subunits distribute almost equally between the two fractions, indicating that this procedure solubilizes approximately 40-50% of the F1-F0 from the inner mitochondrial membrane. The strains P159, E430, and E588 show evidence for mutant β subunits with solubility properties that are comparable to those of the wild type protein. These strains were studied further to determine if the mutant protein is assembled into an F1-F0 complex of the correct size. Soluble Triton X-100 extracts of mitochondria prepared from D273, and from the strains P159, E430, and E588, were centrifuged through linear sucrose gradients and the position of the F1α and β subunit proteins was determined by Western analysis (Fig. 3). The F1 proteins in the mutant and the wild type samples showed comparable sedimentation properties. This result suggests that the A192V, E222K, and R293K mutations do not interfere with the formation of the F1-F0 structure.Fig. 3Western analysis of linear sucrose gradient fractions. Mitochondria, prepared from the yeast strains shown, were extracted with 0.25% Triton X-100, and aliquots of the soluble fractions were centrifuged through 6-20% linear sucrose gradients as described under “Experimental Procedures.” Twenty fractions of equivalent volume were collected from the bottom of the tube, and 15 μl of each fraction were analyzed to detect the F1α and β subunits by Western analysis as described in the legend to Fig. 1. The position of the α and β subunit bands are indicated in the left-hand margin.View Large Image Figure ViewerDownload (PPT) In the mutant strains E210 (P179L mutation), P133 (G133D mutation), and D123 (G227D mutation) virtually all of the β subunit, and most of the α subunit, sediment in the particulate fraction after Triton solubilization of the mitochondrial membrane (data shown for strain E210 in Fig. 2). This pattern of extraction is indicative of a defect in F1-F0 assembly (19Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4986-4990Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). The nature of this defect was investigated further by centrifuging permeabilized mitochondria through 20-80% step-sucrose gradients (see “Experimental Procedures”) to determine if the insoluble F1α and β protein is membrane-bound or in an aggregated form (19Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4986-4990Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). Fractions from the gradient were analyzed on Western blots for the F1α and β subunits and for cytochrome c1. The latter protein remains membrane-bound under the conditions used to permeabilize the mitochondria and serves to mark the position of the inner membrane in the gradient. Fig. 4 shows the results of this experiment for the wild type strain, D273, and for one of the atp2 mutants (E210) that harbors insoluble F1 protein. In the wild type (D273) the F1α and β subunits co-sediment with cytochrome c1 (peak at fraction 6), indicating that most of the F1 remains bound to F0 in the inner membrane under the conditions of the experiment (see also 19Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4986-4990Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). In the mutant strain E210 the F1 subunits migrate separately from cytochrome c1 and peak in the region of high sucrose density (fractions 2 and 3). Results similar to those shown for E210 were obtained with mitochondrial samples from mutant strains P133 and N123 (data not shown). This analysis indicates that the β subunit mutations P179L, G133D, and G227D produce a defect in the assembly of F1 characterized by the intramitochondrial accumulation of α and β subunit in large aggregates (see also 19Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4986-4990Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar). The haploid yeast of the complementation group G1 are complemented in crosses to the wild type, which indicates the strains have recessive mutations in the ATP2 gene. However, in view of the catalytic and structural properties of the F1 enzyme, it may be argued that certain mutations in ATP2 should be partially dominant with respect to a wild type copy of the β subunit gene present in the same cell. There are three β subunits in F1 that are catalytic and the three catalytic sites interact cooperatively during enzyme turnover (1Penefsky H.S. Cross R.L. Adv. Enzymol. 1991; 64: 173-214PubMed Google Scholar, 2Boyer P.D. Biochim. Biophys. Acta. 1993; 1140: 215-250Crossref PubMed Scopus (924) Google Scholar). Studies using chemical (31Bullough D.A. Allison W.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 14171-14177Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) and photoaffinity (32Ackerman S.H. Grubmeyer C. Coleman P.S. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 13765-13772Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) labels have shown that inactivating one of the three β subunits attenuates multisite catalysis in F1. Analysis of hybrid forms of E. coli F1, reconstituted in vitro from mixtures of mutant and wild type subunits (either α (33Rao R. Senior A.E. J. Biol. Chem. 1987; 262: 17450-17454Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar) or β (34Noumi T. Taniai M. Kanazawa H. Futai M. J. Biol. Chem. 1986; 261: 9196-9201Abstract Full Text PDF PubMed Google Scholar)), also show that inactivating a single catalytic site severely impairs F1 steady-state catalysis. These studies support the notion that the co-synthesis of mutant and wild type β subunits can lead to the formation of hybrid enzymes in vivo in which the cooperative interactions are lost. Alternatively, the presence of a mutant β subunit could exert a partially dominant effect by interfering with the assembly of a stable F1 structure. To investigate if the atp2 mutations we identified are partially dominant over wild type ATP2, catalytic activity of the F1-F0 complex was analyzed in diploid strains formed by crossing the atp2 mutants to the wild type yeast, W303-1A. The level of oligomycin-sensitive ATPase was first measured in mitochondrial samples prepared from each of the strains (Table IV). The mitochondria were then extracted with 0.25% Triton X-100, and the amount of solubilized F1-F0 was quantified from Western blots (Fig. 5, Table IV). Finally, the specific activity of the F1-F0 complex was calculated by dividing the percent mitochondrial ATPase activity by the percent solubilized β subunit protein to give the values reported in the last column of Table IV. Support for using these calculations to determine the level of F1-F0 in the yeast diploids comes from the fact that nonassembled F1 is not extracted with Triton X-100 (19Ackerman S.H. Tzagoloff A. Proc. Natl. Acad. Sci. U. S. A. 1990; 87: 4986-4990Crossref PubMed Scopus (130) Google Scholar) and that under identical extraction conditions, the percentage of assembled F1-F0 that is solubilized should be the same in each of the samples. The reference value for F1-F0 catalytic activity is that measured with the double wild type diploid, W303×D273. Interestingly, control amounts of F1-F0 ATPase activity were measured in W303 ∇G1×D273, which is a diploid strain that harbors a single gene for the β subunit (Table IV). This result suggests that expression of ATP2 from either one or two wild type loci provides the diploid cell with the similar complement of the F1-F0 ATP synthaseTable IV.ATPase activity of diploid yeast that synthesize mutant forms of the F1β subunitStrain (mutation)Amount β subunit (soluble)aThe amount of soluble F1β subunit protein was determined using an AMBIS 4000 imaging system to scan Western blots of Triton X-100 mitochondrial extracts. Open table in a new tab Assuming that random interactions occur among the F1 subunits from both parental cells, there is the potential to form four types of enzyme oligomers in the wild type/mutant diploids: a 3βwt, a 3βmut, and two types of hybrids (2βwt1βmut and 1βwt2βmut). All four enzyme types are expected to form in diploids if the resident mutant β subunit does not affect F1 assembly. With respect to the strains shown in Table IV, this situation applies to W303×P159, W303×E430, and W303×E588. In such strains, the 3βwt and 3βmut enzymes are each expected to comprise 12.5% of the total F1 oligomer population; the hybrid forms constitute, cumulatively, the remaining 75% of enzyme (35Walpole R.E. Myers R.H. Probability and Statistics for Engineers and Scientists. 2nd Ed. Macmillan Publishing Co., Inc., New York1978: 12Google Scholar). Since the P159, E430, and E588 haploid strains are devoid of ATPase activity (Table III), it is assumed that the 3βmut F1 formed in the derivative diploid cells is inactive. In cases where the 3βmut F1 is the only inactive form of the enzyme, the maximal level of ATPase activity expected for the diploid strain is 87.5% (cumulative activity from the 3βwt and hybrid enzymes). This value is within 5% error of the ATPase activity observed for W303×P159 (Table IV). Therefore, it would appear that this particular diploid forms fully active F1 hybrids in addition

A purine/pyrimidine mirror repeat element (M-PMR3) in the MUC1 promoter has been shown to form H-DNA under in vitro conditions. We investigated this element for biological function in the regulation of transcription of this gene. Chloramphenicol acetyltransferase reporter-promoter constructs were prepared in which the mirror repeat element (PMR3) was intact, deleted, or modified, and their activities were evaluated by transient transfection assays into the cell lines Capan-2, PANC1, and HT-29. Deletion or modification of M-PMR3 increased expression of chloramphenicol acetyltransferase activity in MUC1-expressing cells; however, a role for an H-DNA structure in this activity was not supported by the results.
